In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful.
Indeed, all praise is due to Allah; we praise Him, seek His help, and ask for His forgiveness. We seek refuge in Allah from the evils of our souls and the bad consequences of our deeds. Whomsoever Allah guides, none can lead astray, and whomsoever He leaves astray, none can guide. I testify that there is no deity worthy of worship except Allah alone, having no partners, and I testify that Muhammad is His slave and Messenger.

To proceed: The interest of facilitating the review of funeral rulings necessitated that I summarize them and bring their rulings closer to those who wish to refer to them and gain a quick general idea about them, especially when an occasion arises, such as the death of a relative or a loved one. It is no secret that referring to my book 'Ahkam al-Jana'iz wa Bida'uha' (Funeral Rulings and Their Innovations), reading it entirely, and comprehending all the necessary rulings contained within it during such a situation is not feasible for most people.

Therefore, I saw fit to summarize it and bring its benefits closer to the general readers. By doing so, I would have fulfilled the desire of that dear brother who was the direct reason for composing 'Al-Ahkam', as I mentioned in its introduction. It is a desire shared by many who love the Prophetic Sunnah and are keen on reviving it in various lands of the world, both Arab and non-Arab. Some even proceeded in Egypt to abridge the book without my permission or knowledge. Perhaps they intended only the reward in the Hereafter. However, many publishers and printers have started stealing my books and printing them to trade in them and consume their profits as illicit gain. The insolence of some of them reached the point where they printed on it the phrase 'Printed by The Islamic Office', thereby being a lying deceiver. We used to complain, and still do, about the theft of books and printing them as they are using the offset method. But lo and behold, this particular one had the audacity to print it by typesetting the letters and printing it anew, deceiving people that it is from the print of 'The Islamic Office' by printing the name of the Office on it. It has reached me that some of them issued a fatwa permitting the theft of books, printing them, and trading in them without the permission of their author and publisher. This is flagrant injustice and dishonorable exploitation of the efforts of others among authors and publishers who have taken writing and publishing as one of the most honorable means of earning a lawful livelihood. How does it befit a Muslim, nay even a disbeliever, to cut off the livelihood of these people and consume the profit of their efforts and toil himself, let alone issuing a fatwa permitting it? By Allah, it is indeed one of the great [sins]!

It is strange that Western men become aware of such injustice and enact just laws to protect the rights of authors and publishers and to intervene between thieves and their injustice, yet some Muslims do not notice it, even though they know that their religion prohibits injustice absolutely, as in the saying of the Exalted in the Hadith Qudsi: 'O My servants, I have forbidden injustice for Myself and have made it forbidden amongst you, so do not oppress one another...' Narrated by Muslim in his Sahih. And the saying of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): 'Beware of injustice, for injustice will be darknesses on the Day of Resurrection.' Narrated by Al-Bukhari and Muslim.

I have heard from some foolish people who have no understanding that they deem such theft permissible under the pretext of spreading knowledge. Allah knows that the thieves have no concern for spreading knowledge; rather, their concern is gathering money through the efforts of others. The proof is that they may print books that do not please them from a scholarly or madhhab perspective, and that is only because they know of their popularity and people's demand for them. Yet, they proceed to print and steal them, acting upon the rule of those who have no morals: 'the end justifies the means'. Allah is their reckoner. {And the Day the wrongdoer will bite on his hands [in regret] he will say, "Oh, I wish I had taken with the Messenger a way."} [Al-Furqan: 27].

Know, O noble reader, that in this summary, I have omitted the referencing (Takhrij) of the hadiths, sufficing with the original source, and because we adhered to authenticity in it as is our custom in all our writings, praise be to Allah always and forever. I also deleted some of its texts and many of the comments that do not have a strong connection to the subject of the book, and I added a few benefits that were not in the original.

I ask Allah to make it beneficial for the Muslims and to make it, like its original and all my other writings, an aid for them in following the Book and the Sunnah and in resuming the Islamic life, to which there is no way except through beneficial knowledge and righteous action. Indeed, He is Hearing and Responsive.

Amman - Jordan, 13 Jumada al-Akhira, 1402 AH.
Muhammad Nasir al-Din al-Albani.

1- What is obligatory upon the sick person

1 - The sick person must be satisfied with the decree of Allah, be patient with His destiny, and think well of his Lord. That is better for him, due to the saying of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): 'How wonderful is the affair of the believer; his affair is all good, and this is for no one except the believer. If prosperity befalls him, he is thankful, so it is good for him. And if adversity befalls him, he is patient, so it is good for him.' And his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): 'None of you should die except while he thinks well of Allah the Exalted.'

2 - He should be between fear and hope; fearing Allah's punishment for his sins and hoping for the mercy of his Lord, due to the hadith of Anas known in Al-Tirmidhi and others: That the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) entered upon a young man who was dying and said: 'How do you find yourself?' He said: 'By Allah, O Messenger of Allah, indeed I hope in Allah and I fear my sins.' The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: 'These two do not gather in the heart of a servant in such a situation except that Allah gives him what he hopes for and secures him from what he fears.'

3 - No matter how severe the illness becomes, it is not permissible for him to wish for death. [Authentic]. If he must do so, let him say: 'O Allah, keep me alive as long as life is good for me, and cause me to die if death is better for me.'

4 - If he has rights [debts/obligations] owed to others, he must restore them to their owners if that is easy for him; otherwise, he must advise [make a will] regarding them, due to his command (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) regarding that.

5 - One must hasten with such a will, due to his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): 'It is not right for a Muslim man who has something he wants to make a bequest about to sleep for two nights except that his will is written at his head.' Ibn Umar said:

'No night has passed me since I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) say that, except that my will is with me.'

6 - He must make a bequest for relatives who do not inherit from him, due to the saying of Allah the Blessed and Exalted: {Prescribed for you when death approaches [any] one of you if he leaves wealth [is that he should make] a bequest for the parents and near relatives according to what is acceptable - a duty upon the righteous.} [Al-Baqarah: 180].

7 - [Authentic]. He may bequeath one-third of his wealth, and it is not permissible to exceed that. Rather, it is better to reduce it, due to the hadith of Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas (may Allah be pleased with him) established in the Two Sahihs: 'I was with the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) during the Farewell Pilgrimage, and I became sick with an illness that brought me to the brink of death. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) visited me, so I said: O Messenger of Allah, I have much wealth and no one inherits from me except a daughter of mine. Shall I bequeath two-thirds of my money? He said: No. I said: Half of my money? He said: No. I said: Then one-third of my money? He said: The third, and the third is much. Indeed, O Sa'd, that you leave your heirs rich is better for you than leaving them dependent, begging from people.' And he gestured with his hand, 'Indeed, O Sa'd, you will never spend a specific amount seeking thereby the Face of Allah the Exalted except that you will be rewarded for it, even the morsel you place in the mouth of your wife.' He said: So afterwards, the third became permissible. And due to the saying of Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with him): 'I wish people would reduce from the third to the quarter in the will, because the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: The third is much.'

8 - Two just Muslim men should witness that. If they cannot be found, then two men from non-Muslims, provided that verification is sought from them in case of doubt regarding their testimony, as explained in the saying of Allah the Blessed and Exalted: {O you who have believed, testimony [should be taken] among you when death approaches one of you at the time of bequest - [that of] two just men from among you or two others from outside if you are traveling through the land and the disaster of death should strike you. Detain them after the prayer and let them swear by Allah if you doubt, [saying], "We will not exchange it...

...for a price, even if he should be a near relative, and we will not conceal the testimony of Allah. Indeed, we would then be of the sinful." But if it is found that those two were guilty of sin, then two others shall stand in their place [who are] foremost [in claim] from those who have a lawful right. And let them swear by Allah, "Our testimony is truer than their testimony, and we have not transgressed. Indeed, we would then be of the wrongdoers."} {That is more likely that they will give testimony according to its [true] objective or fear that oaths will be taken after their oaths. And fear Allah and listen; and Allah does not guide the defiantly disobedient people.} [Al-Ma'idah: 106-108].

9 - As for a bequest to parents and relatives who inherit from the testator, it is not permissible because it is abrogated by the verse of inheritance. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) clarified this most perfectly in his sermon during the Farewell Pilgrimage, saying: 'Indeed, Allah has given every one with a right his right, so there is no bequest for an heir.'

10 - It is prohibited to cause harm in the will, such as bequeathing to deprive some heirs of their right to inheritance or favoring some over others in it, due to the saying of Allah the Blessed and Exalted: {For men is a share of what the parents and close relatives leave... from what is little or much - an obligatory share.} ... Then He said: {...after any bequest he [may have] made or debt, not being harmful [to the heirs]. An ordinance from Allah, and Allah is Knowing and Forbearing.} [An-Nisa: 7, 12]. And due to his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): 'There should be no harming and no reciprocation of harm. Whoever harms [others], Allah will harm him, and whoever causes difficulty, Allah will cause difficulty for him.'

11 - An unjust will is void and rejected, due to his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): 'Whoever introduces into this matter of ours that which is not from it, it is rejected.'
foot_note: 1. Meaning: If it is discovered that the two witnesses who swore the oath deserved sin by lying and concealing in the testimony, or by treachery and concealing something of the estate while trusted with it, then the obligation, or what is done to establish the truth, is that the oath returns to the heirs. Two other men stand in their place from the relatives of the deceased who are his heirs, those against whom the first two committed the sin by offending them and betraying them. This is in Tafsir al-Manar, and refer to the complete discussion in it 7/222.

12 - Since innovation in religion has become prevalent among many people in this time, especially regarding funerals, it has become obligatory for a Muslim to leave a will that he be prepared and buried according to the Sunnah, acting upon the saying of the Exalted: {O you who have believed, protect yourselves and your families from a Fire whose fuel is people and stones, over which are [appointed] angels, harsh and severe; they do not disobey Allah in what He commands them but do what they are commanded.} [At-Tahrim: 6].

For this reason, the Companions of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to leave wills to that effect. The reports from them regarding what we mentioned are numerous; refer to them in the original [book]. Among them: From Hudhayfah who said: 'If I die, do not proclaim my death to anyone, for I fear that it would be a form of Na'i (forbidden death announcement), and I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) forbidding Na'i.'

For this reason, Al-Nawawi, may Allah have mercy on him, said in Al-Adhkar: 'It is recommended for him, a confirmed recommendation, to advise them to avoid the innovations that have become customary in funerals, and to emphasize the covenant regarding that.'

Prompting the Dying (Talqin)

13 - If death approaches him, then those present must do several things:

A - They should prompt him to say the Shahada, due to his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): 'Prompt your dying ones to say La ilaha illa Allah. Whoever's last words are La ilaha illa Allah at death will enter Paradise one day in time, even if he is afflicted before that with whatever he is afflicted.'

B & C - They should supplicate for him and say nothing but good in his presence, due to his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): 'If you visit the sick or the dead, then say good, for the angels say Amen to what you say.'

14 - Prompting (Talqin) is not merely mentioning the Shahada in the presence of the dying person and letting him hear it; rather, it is commanding him to say it, contrary to what some think. The proof is the hadith of Anas (may Allah be pleased with him): That the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) visited a man from the Ansar and said: 'O Uncle, say: La ilaha illa Allah.' He said: '[Am I] a maternal uncle or a paternal uncle?' He said: 'Rather, a maternal uncle.' He said: 'Is it better for me to say: La ilaha illa Allah?' The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: 'Yes.'

15 - As for reading Surah Ya-Sin in his presence and directing him towards the Qiblah, no hadith is authentic regarding this. Rather, Sa'id bin al-Musayyib disliked directing him towards it and said: 'Is the dead person not a Muslim?' Narrated from Zur'ah bin Abdur-Rahman that he attended Sa'id bin al-Musayyib during his illness, and Abu Salamah bin Abdur-Rahman was with him. Sa'id fainted, so Abu Salamah ordered that his bed be turned towards the Kaaba. When he woke up, he said: 'Did you turn my bed?' They said: 'Yes.' He looked at Abu Salamah and said: 'I think it was by your knowledge?' He said: 'I ordered them.' So Sa'id ordered that his bed be returned [to its original position].

16 - There is no harm for a Muslim to attend the death of a disbeliever to present Islam to him in the hope that he accepts it, due to the hadith of Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: A Jewish boy used to serve the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), and he fell sick. The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) came to visit him and sat by his head. He said to him: 'Accept Islam.' He looked at his father who was with him. He [the father] said to him: 'Obey Abu al-Qasim.' So he accepted Islam. The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) went out saying: 'Praise be to Allah who saved him from the Fire.' When he died, he said: 'Pray over your companion.'

3- What is incumbent upon those present after his death.

17 - If he passes away and the soul departs, they must do several things:

A & B - They should close his eyes and supplicate for him as well, due to the hadith of Umm Salamah who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) entered upon Abu Salamah while his eyes were fixed open. He closed them and then said: 'Indeed, when the soul is taken, the sight follows it.' Some people from his family wailed, so he said: 'Do not supplicate against yourselves except for good, for the angels say Amen to what you say.' Then he said: 'O Allah, forgive Abu Salamah, raise his degree among the guided, grant him a successor in his descendants who remain, forgive us and him, O Lord of the worlds, make his grave spacious for him, and illuminate it for him.'

C - They should cover him with a garment that conceals his entire body, due to the hadith of Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her): That the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), when he passed away, was covered with a Hibara garment [a type of Yemeni sheet].

D - This applies to someone who did not die while in the state of Ihram. As for the Muhrim, his head and face are not covered, due to the hadith of Ibn Abbas who said: While a man was standing at Arafat, he fell from his mount and it broke his neck [or he said: killed him]. The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: 'Wash him with water and sidr (lote-tree leaves) and shroud him in two garments' - and in a narration: 'in his two garments in which he assumed Ihram'... 'And do not embalm him' - and in a narration: 'do not apply perfume to him, and do not cover his head or his face, for he will be resurrected on the Day of Resurrection reciting the Talbiyah.'

E - They should hasten to prepare him and take him out if his death is confirmed, due to the hadith of Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him), traceable to the Prophet: 'Hasten with the funeral...' The Hadith will follow in full in Issue 50.

F - They should bury him in the land where he died and not transfer him to another, because that contradicts the hastening commanded in the hadith of Abu Hurayrah mentioned previously.

Therefore, Aisha said when a brother of hers died in the valley of Abyssinia and was carried from his place: 'Nothing I feel within myself or that saddens me creates regret except that I wish he had been buried in his place.' Al-Nawawi said in Al-Adhkar: 'If he directed in his will to be transferred to another land, his will is not executed, for the transfer is forbidden (Haram) according to the correct chosen view stated by the majority and explicitly mentioned by the investigators.'

G - Some of them should hasten to pay off his debt from his wealth, even if it consumes all of it. If he has no wealth, the state must pay it on his behalf if he had striven to pay it. If the state does not do so, and some people volunteer to do it, it is permissible. There are hadiths regarding this which you can see in the original [book].

4- What is permissible for those present and others.

18 - It is permissible for them to uncover the face of the deceased and kiss him between his eyes, due to Abu Bakr kissing the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) after his death, and weeping over him for three days. This is due to the authentic hadith of Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) who said: Abu Bakr (may Allah be pleased with him) came on his horse from his dwelling in Al-Sunh until he dismounted. He entered the mosque while Umar was speaking to the people. He did not speak to the people until he entered upon Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) and approached the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), who was covered with a Hibara garment. He uncovered his face, then leaned over him and kissed him between his eyes, then wept and said: 'May my father and mother be sacrificed for you, O Prophet of Allah. Allah will not combine two deaths upon you. As for the death which was written for you, you have died it.' And in a narration: 'You have died the death after which you will never die.'

And the hadith of Abdullah bin Ja'far (may Allah be pleased with him): That the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) gave the family of Ja'far three days respite to come to them, then he came to them and said: 'Do not weep over my brother after this day.' ... The Hadith. Its wording will come in the section on Condolences, if Allah the Exalted wills. [Authentic].

And the hadith of Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: We entered with the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) upon Abu Sayf - who was the wet nurse's husband for Ibrahim (peace be upon him). The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) took Ibrahim, kissed him, and smelled him. Then we entered upon him after that while Ibrahim was breathing his last. The eyes of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) began to shed tears. Abdur-Rahman bin Awf said to him: 'Even you, O Messenger of Allah?' He said: 'O Ibn Awf, indeed it is mercy.' Then he followed it with another [tear] and said: 'Indeed the eye tears and the heart grieves, and we do not say except what pleases our Lord. And indeed, by your separation, O Ibrahim, we are saddened.'

5- What is obligatory upon the relatives of the deceased.

19 - When the news of his death reaches the relatives of the deceased, two things are obligatory upon them:

First: Patience and acceptance of the decree, due to the saying of the Exalted: {And We will surely test you with something of fear and hunger and a loss of wealth and lives and fruits, but give good tidings to the patient, Who, when disaster strikes them, say, "Indeed we belong to Allah, and indeed to Him we will return." Those are the ones upon whom are blessings from their Lord and mercy. And it is those who are the [rightly] guided.} [Al-Baqarah: 155-157]. And due to the hadith of Anas bin Malik (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) passed by a woman at a grave who was weeping. He said to her: 'Fear Allah and be patient.' She said: 'Go away from me, for you have not been afflicted with my calamity.' He said: She did not recognize him. It was said to her: 'He is the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him).' She was seized by something like death. She came to the door of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and did not find doorkeepers there. She said: 'O Messenger of Allah, I did not recognize you.' The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: 'Indeed, patience is at the first shock.'

Patience over the death of children has a great reward, and many hadiths have come regarding that. I mention some of them:

First: 'No two Muslims have three children die who have not reached the age of puberty except that Allah and their parents enter Paradise by the virtue of His mercy.' He said: 'And they will be at one of the gates of Paradise, and it will be said to them: Enter Paradise. They will say: Not until our parents come. It will be said to them: Enter Paradise, you and your parents, by the virtue of Allah's mercy.'

Second: 'Any woman who has three children die, they will be a screen for her from the Fire.' A woman said: 'And two?' He said: 'And two.'

Second: Istirja', which is to say: 'Inna lillahi wa inna ilayhi raji'un' (Indeed we belong to Allah, and indeed to Him we will return) based on the preceding verse. And one adds to it his saying: 'O Allah, reward me in my calamity and replace it for me with something better than it', due to the hadith of Umm Salamah in Sahih Muslim and others.

20 - It does not contradict patience for a woman to refrain from all adornment in mourning for the death of her child or other than him, provided she does not exceed three days, except for her husband, for whom she mourns four months and ten days. This is due to the hadith of Zaynab bint Abi Salamah who said: I entered upon Umm Habibah, the wife of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), and she said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) say: 'It is not lawful for a woman who believes in Allah and the Last Day to mourn for a dead person more than three nights, except for a husband, [for whom she mourns] four months and ten days.' Then I entered upon Zaynab bint Jahsh when her brother died. She called for perfume and applied it, then said: 'I have no need for perfume, except that I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) say: ...' and she mentioned the hadith.

21 - However, if she does not mourn for other than her husband to please the husband and to fulfill his need for her, it is better for her, and much good is hoped for both of them from that, as happened to Umm Sulaym and her husband Abu Talha al-Ansari (may Allah be pleased with them both). Their story regarding that is long, and were it not for that, I would have cited it here; so let it be referred to in the original [book].

6- What is prohibited for the relatives of the deceased.

22 - The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) prohibited matters that some people used to commit - and still do - when a death occurs among them. It is obligatory to know them to avoid them, so they must be clarified:

A - Wailing (Niyaha). There are many hadiths regarding it which you can see in the original, among them his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): 'Two things in people are Kufr (disbelief/ingratitude) for them: Defaming lineage and wailing over the dead.'

B & C - Slapping cheeks and tearing pockets (garments), due to his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): 'He is not of us who slaps the cheeks, tears the pockets, and calls with the call of Jahiliyyah (Pre-Islamic ignorance).'

D - Shaving the hair, due to the hadith of Abu Burdah bin Abi Musa who said: [Authentic] Abu Musa became sick with an illness and fainted, and his head was in the lap of a woman from his family. A woman from his family screamed, but he was unable to answer her with anything. When he woke up, he said: 'I am innocent of whom the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) declared himself innocent. Indeed, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) declared himself innocent of the Saliqah, the Haliqah, and the Shaqqah.'

E - Spreading the hair (disheveling), due to the hadith of a woman among those who pledged allegiance, who said: Among what the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) took from us in the pledge of righteousness that we would not disobey him in, was that we should not scratch a face, nor call out 'Woe', nor tear a pocket, nor spread hair.

F - Some men letting their beards grow for a few days in grief for their deceased, then when the days pass, they return to shaving them. This letting grow is in the meaning of spreading the hair as is apparent. Added to that, it is an innovation, and he (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: 'Every innovation is a misguidance, and every misguidance is in the Fire.'

2. She is the one who raises her voice during the calamity of death.

Knowing that adorning oneself by shaving it - as most do - is a manifest disobedience by the agreement of the four Imams and others, due to its contradiction of various legal evidences as you can see clarified in 'Adab al-Zafaf' (Etiquette of Wedding) p. 118 – 123.

G - Announcing his death from the tops of minarets and similar places, because it is from Na'i (forbidden announcement). It is established from Hudhayfah bin al-Yaman that: 'When a dead person died among his [family], he would say: Do not proclaim him to anyone, for I fear that it would be Na'i. Indeed, I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) forbidding Na'i.'

7- Permissible Announcement (Na'i)

23 - It is permissible to announce the death if it is not accompanied by what resembles the Na'i of Jahiliyyah. This may become obligatory if there is no one with him to fulfill his rights of washing, shrouding, and praying over him, and similar matters, due to the hadith of Abu Hurayrah: 'That the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) announced the death of Al-Najashi on the day he died...' The Hadith.

24 - It is recommended for the informer to ask people to seek forgiveness for the deceased, due to his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in the story of his prayer over Al-Najashi: 'Seek forgiveness for your brother.' This will be discussed in Issue 60 / Seventh.

I say: So the saying of people in some countries: 'Al-Fatihah for the soul of so-and-so' is contrary to the mentioned Sunnah, so it is an innovation without doubt, especially since recitation does not reach the dead according to the correct view, as will be discussed if Allah the Exalted wills.

8- Signs of a Good Ending.

25 - Furthermore, the Wise Lawgiver has set clear signs by which a good ending can be inferred - Allah has written them for us by His grace and favor. So whoever dies with one of them, it is a glad tiding for him, and what a glad tiding it is.

First: Pronouncing the Shahada at death. There are hadiths mentioned in the original regarding this, including his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): 'He whose last words are La ilaha illa Allah enters Paradise.'

Second: Dying with sweat on the forehead, due to the hadith of Buraydah bin al-Hasib (may Allah be pleased with him): [Authentic] That he was in Khurasan and visited a brother of his who was sick. He found him dying, and behold, he was sweating on his forehead. He said: 'Allah is Great! I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) say: The death of a believer is with sweat on the forehead.'

Third: [The hadith is Hasan or Sahih with the sum of its paths] Dying on the night of Friday or its day, due to his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): 'There is no Muslim who dies on Friday or the night of Friday except that Allah protects him from the trial of the grave.'

Fourth: Martyrdom on the battlefield. Allah the Exalted said: {And never think of those who have been killed in the cause of Allah as dead. Rather, they are alive with their Lord, receiving provision. Rejoicing in what Allah has bestowed upon them of His bounty, and they receive good tidings about those [to be martyred] after them who have not yet joined them - that there will be no fear concerning them, nor will they grieve. They receive good tidings of favor from Allah and bounty and [of the fact] that Allah does not allow the reward of believers to be lost.} [Al-Imran: 169-171]. And he (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: 'The martyr has six qualities with Allah: He is forgiven with the first flow of his blood, he sees his seat in Paradise, he is protected from the punishment of the grave, he is secured from the Greatest Terror, he is adorned with the garment of faith, he is married to the Hoor al-Ayn, and he intercedes for seventy people of his relatives.'

Fifth: Dying as a fighter (Ghazi) in the cause of Allah, due to his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): 'What do you consider the martyr among you?' They said: 'O Messenger of Allah, whoever is killed in the cause of Allah is a martyr.' He said: 'Indeed, the martyrs of my nation would then be few.' They said: 'Then who are they, O Messenger of Allah?' He said: 'Whoever is killed in the cause of Allah is a martyr, whoever dies in the cause of Allah is a martyr, whoever dies of the plague is a martyr, whoever dies of an abdominal ailment is a martyr, and the drowned person is a martyr.'

Sixth: Dying of the plague. There are hadiths regarding it, including his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): 'The plague is martyrdom for every Muslim.'

Seventh: Dying of an abdominal ailment, due to his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in the previous hadith: 'And whoever dies in the belly [abdominal ailment] is a martyr.'

Eighth and Ninth: Dying by drowning and by a building collapsing, due to his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): 'The martyrs are five: The one who dies of plague, the one with an abdominal ailment, the drowned, the one who dies under debris, and the martyr in the cause of Allah.'

Tenth: The death of a woman in her postpartum period due to her child, due to the hadith of Ubadah bin al-Samit: That the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) visited Abdullah bin Rawahah. He said: He moved aside from his bed for him. He said: 'Do you know who the martyrs of my nation are?' They said: 'Being killed as a Muslim is martyrdom.' He said: 'Indeed, the martyrs of my nation would then be few. Being killed as a Muslim is martyrdom, the plague is martyrdom, and the woman killed by her child [in childbirth] - Jum'aa - is martyrdom; her child drags her by his umbilical cord into Paradise.'

Eleventh and Twelfth: Death by burning and Pleurisy. There are hadiths regarding this, the most famous being from Jabir bin Atik, traceable to the Prophet: 'Martyrs are seven besides killing in the cause of Allah: The one who dies of plague is a martyr, the drowned is a martyr, the one with pleurisy is a martyr, the one with an abdominal ailment is a martyr, the one who dies by burning is a martyr, the one who dies under debris is a martyr, and the woman who dies with a child (Jum'aa) is a martyr.'

Fifteenth and Sixteenth: Dying in defense of religion and self, due to his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): 'Whoever is killed protecting his property is a martyr, whoever is killed protecting his family is a martyr, whoever is killed protecting his religion is a martyr, and whoever is killed protecting his blood is a martyr.'

9- People's praise of the deceased.

26 - Praise with good for the deceased from a group of truthful Muslims - the least being two of his neighbors who knew him, from people of righteousness and knowledge - necessitates Paradise for him. There are hadiths regarding this:

First: From Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: A funeral passed by the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and it was praised with good, and tongues followed one another with good. They said: 'He used to - as far as we know - love Allah and His Messenger.' So the Prophet of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: 'It has become binding, it has become binding, it has become binding.' Then a funeral passed and it was praised with evil, and tongues followed one another with evil. They said: 'What a wretched man he was in the religion of Allah.' So the Prophet of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: 'It has become binding, it has become binding, it has become binding.' Umar said: 'May my father and mother be sacrificed for you. A funeral passed and was praised with good, so you said: It has become binding, it has become binding, it has become binding. And a funeral passed and was praised with evil, so you said: It has become binding, it has become binding, it has become binding?' The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: 'Whoever you praised with good, Paradise has become binding for him. And whoever you praised with evil, the Fire has become binding for him. The angels are witnesses in Allah in the heaven, and you are Allah's witnesses on earth, you are Allah's witnesses on earth, you are Allah's witnesses on earth.' And in a narration: 'And the believers are Allah's witnesses on earth; indeed, Allah has angels who speak upon the tongues of the sons of Adam regarding what is in a person of good and evil.'

Second: From Abu al-Aswad al-Dili who said: I came to Medina while a disease had occurred in it, and they were dying a rapid death. I sat with Umar bin al-Khattab (may Allah be pleased with him), and a funeral passed by, and it was praised with good. Umar said: 'It is binding.' I said: 'What is binding, O Commander of the Faithful?' He said: 'I said as the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: Any Muslim for whom four testify with good, Allah enters him into Paradise.' We said: 'And three?' He said: 'And three.' We said: 'And two?' He said: 'And two.' Then we did not ask him about one.

Third: 'No Muslim dies and four from the people of the households of his nearest neighbors testify that they do not know anything but good about him, except that Allah the Blessed and Exalted says: I have accepted your statement - or he said: your testimony - and I have forgiven him for what you do not know.'

Know that the sum of these three hadiths indicates that this testimony is not specific to the Companions, but it is also for those after them among the believers who follow their path in faith, knowledge, and truthfulness. Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar asserted this in Al-Fath, so let whoever wants more explanation refer to his words.

Furthermore, the restriction of the testimony to four in the third hadith appears to have been before the hadith of Umar which preceded it, for in it [Umar's hadith] the testimony of two is sufficient, and it is the reliance.

As for people's saying after the funeral prayer: 'What do you testify regarding him? Testify good for him,' and they answer by saying: 'Righteous' or 'From the people of goodness' and similar things, this is not what is intended by the hadith at all. Rather, it is an ugly innovation because it was not from the practice of the Salaf (Predecessors), and because those who testify to that do not know the deceased in most cases. Indeed, they may testify contrary to what they know in response to the desire of the one asking for testimony of good, thinking that this benefits the deceased, and being ignorant that the beneficial testimony is only that which matches reality in the soul of the witness, as indicated by his saying in the hadith: 'Indeed, Allah has angels who speak upon the tongues of the sons of Adam regarding what is in a person of good and evil.'

Death during Eclipses?

27 - If the death of someone coincides with the eclipse of the sun or the moon, this does not indicate anything. Believing that it indicates the greatness of the deceased is merely from the superstitions of Jahiliyyah which the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) invalidated the day his son Ibrahim (peace be upon him) died and the sun eclipsed. He addressed the people, praised Allah and extolled Him, then said: [Authentic] 'To proceed, O people, indeed the people of Jahiliyyah used to say: The sun and the moon do not eclipse except for the death of a great person. Indeed, they are two signs from the signs of Allah; they do not eclipse for the death of anyone nor for his life. Rather, Allah frightens His servants with them. So if you see anything of that, then hasten to His remembrance, supplicating Him, seeking His forgiveness, giving charity, freeing slaves, and praying in the mosques until it clears.'

10- Washing the Dead (Ghusl)

28 - When the dead person dies, it is obligatory upon a group of people to hasten to wash him. As for hastening, its evidence has preceded in Chapter Three, Issue 17, Paragraph E. As for the obligation of washing, it is due to his command (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) regarding it in more than one hadith:

First: His saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) regarding the Muhrim whose she-camel broke his neck: 'Wash him with water and sidr...' The Hadith. It has passed in full in the indicated Issue, Paragraph D.

Second: His saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) regarding his daughter Zaynab (may Allah be pleased with her): 'Wash her three times, or five, or seven... or more than that...' The Hadith, and it will come in full in the following Issue.

29 - The following matters are observed in washing him:

First: Washing him three times or more, according to what those undertaking his washing see fit.

Second: That the washings be odd in number.

Third: That sidr or what takes its place in cleaning, such as potash (ushnan) and soap, be combined with some of them.

Fourth: That some perfume be mixed with the last washing, and camphor is preferable.

Fifth: Undoing the braids and washing them thoroughly.

Sixth: Combing his hair.

Seventh: Making it into three braids for a woman and placing them behind her.

Eighth: Starting with his right side and the places of ablution (Wudu).

Ninth: That men undertake washing a male and women undertake washing a female, except what is exempted as will be clarified.

The evidence for these matters is the Hadith of Umm Atiyyah (may Allah be pleased with her), who said: [Authentic] The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) entered upon us while we were washing his daughter Zainab, and he said: 'Wash her three, five, or seven times, or more than that if you see fit.' She said: I said: 'An odd number?' He said: 'Yes, and put camphor or something of camphor in the last washing. Then when you have finished, notify me.' So when we finished, we notified him, and he threw his *haqw* (waist wrapper) 1 to us and said: 'Make it her *shi'ar* (undergarment)' 2, meaning his Izar (lower garment). She said: And we combed her hair into three braids. In a narration: We undid it, washed it, and braided her hair into three thirds: her two horns (sides) and her forelock, and we threw them behind her. She said: And he said to us: 'Start with her right side and the places of ablution on her.'

Tenth: That he be washed with a cloth or the like under a cover for his body after stripping him of all his clothes, for that is how the practice was during the time of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), as indicated by the Hadith of Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her): When they wanted to wash the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), they said: 'By Allah, we do not know whether to strip the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) of his clothes as we strip our dead, or to wash him while his clothes are upon him?' When they differed, Allah cast sleep upon them until there was not a man among them but his chin was on his chest. Then a speaker spoke to them from the side of the house, they did not know who he was: 'Wash the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) while his clothes are upon him.' So they stood up to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and washed him while his shirt was on him, pouring water over the shirt and rubbing him with the shirt and not their hands. Aisha used to say: 'If I had known beforehand what I know now, no one would have washed him except his wives.'

Eleventh: [Good/Hasan] The purpose of covering his body and using a cloth is so that his *'Awrah* (private parts) are not seen or touched. The *'Awrah* of a man is from the navel to the knee according to the correct view, due to his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): 'What is between the navel and the knee is *'Awrah*.' 1 [Authentic] And his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): 'The thigh is *'Awrah*.' 2 As for a woman with a Muslim woman - naturally - she is *'Awrah* except for the places of adornment, which are the head, the ear, the neck, and the upper chest (place of the necklace), and the forearm with part of the upper arm (place of the armband), and the foot and lower leg (place of the anklet). Whatever is other than that is *'Awrah*; it is not permissible for a woman - like the *Mahrams* - to look at any of it, nor for her to reveal it, due to the explicit saying of Allah the Exalted: {And not display their adornment except what is apparent thereof and let them wrap their headcovers over their chests and not display their adornment except to their husbands, their fathers, their husbands' fathers, their sons, their husbands' sons, their brothers, their brothers' sons, their sisters' sons, or their women...} the Verse 3.

Twelfth: An exception to what was mentioned in point four is the *Muhrim* (pilgrim in state of consecration); it is not permissible to perfume him, due to his saying in the Hadith referred to shortly before: 'Do not put *Hanoot* (perfume) on him,' and in a narration: 'And do not perfume him... for he will be resurrected on the Day of Judgment reciting the Talbiyah.'

Thirteenth: Also exempted from what was mentioned in point nine are the spouses. It is permissible for each of them to wash the other, as there is no evidence to prevent it, and the default ruling is permissibility, especially since it is supported by two Hadiths:
The First: [Authentic] The saying of Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) in her previously mentioned Hadith: 'If I had known beforehand what I know now, no one would have washed the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) except his wives.'

The Second: Also from her, she said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) returned to me from a funeral at Al-Baqi', and I was suffering a headache and saying: 'Oh, my head!' He said: 'Rather, I, oh my head! What would harm you if you died before me, so I washed you, shrouded you, prayed over you, and buried you?'

Fourteenth: Those who are most knowledgeable about the Sunnah of washing should undertake his washing, especially if they are from his family and relatives, because those who undertook washing him (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) were as we mentioned. Ali (may Allah be pleased with him) said: 'I washed the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and I began to look for what usually comes from the deceased, but I saw nothing. He was pure in life and in death, may the peace and blessings of Allah be upon him.'

30 - There is a great reward for the one who undertakes washing him, subject to two conditions:
The First: That he conceals him and does not speak of any dislikeable things he might see, due to his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): 'Whoever washes a Muslim and conceals him, Allah will forgive him forty times. And whoever digs a grave for him and buries him, he will be granted a reward like that of a dwelling he provided for him until the Day of Judgment. And whoever shrouds him, Allah will clothe him on the Day of Judgment with silk and brocade of Paradise.'

The Second: That he seeks the Face of Allah by that, desiring neither reward nor thanks nor anything of worldly matters, as it is established in the Sharia that Allah, Blessed and Exalted, does not accept acts of worship unless they are purely for His Noble Face. The evidences for this from the Book and Sunnah are very many; I will suffice here with mentioning two of them:
The First: The saying of Allah, Blessed and Exalted: {Say, "I am only a man like you, to whom has been revealed that your god is one God. So whoever would hope for the meeting with his Lord - let him do righteous work and not associate in the worship of his Lord anyone."} Meaning: He does not intend by it other than the Face of Allah the Exalted.

The Second: His saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): "Actions are only by intentions, and every person will have only what he intended. So whoever's emigration was to Allah and His Messenger, then his emigration was to Allah and His Messenger. And whoever's emigration was to a worldly gain he would achieve or a woman he would marry, then his emigration was to that for which he emigrated."

31 - It is recommended for the one who washed him to perform Ghusl (a full bath), due to his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): "Whoever washes a dead person, let him perform Ghusl, and whoever carries him, let him perform Wudu (ablution)." The apparent meaning of the command implies obligation, but we did not say it is obligatory due to two Hadiths:
The First: His saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): "You are not obligated to perform Ghusl for washing your dead, for if you wash him, your dead is not impure. It is sufficient for you to wash your hands."
The Second: The saying of Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with him): "We used to wash the dead; some of us would perform Ghusl and some of us would not perform Ghusl."

32 - It is not legislated to wash the martyr slain in battle, even if he happened to be *Junub* (in a state of major ritual impurity), and regarding that are several Hadiths:
The First: From Jabir who said: The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Bury them in their blood" - meaning on the day of Uhud - and he did not wash them. And in a narration, he said: "I am a witness over these. Wrap them in their blood, for there is no wound suffered for the sake of Allah except that it will come on the Day of Judgment bleeding; its color is the color of blood and its scent is the scent of musk." And in a narration: "Do not wash them, for every wound will exude musk on the Day of Judgment." And he did not pray over them.

The Second: From Abu Barzah that the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was in a campaign of his, and Allah granted him booty. He said to his companions: "Are you missing anyone?" They said: "Yes, so-and-so, so-and-so, and so-and-so." Then he said: "Are you missing anyone?" They said: "No." He said: "But I am missing Julaibib.

Search for him." So he was searched for among the dead and was found beside seven whom he had killed, then they killed him. The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) came to him, stood over him, and said: "He killed seven then they killed him. He is from me and I am from him; he is from me and I am from him." He said it twice or three times. Then he extended his arms like this and spread them out. He said: So he placed him on his forearms; he had no bed except the forearms of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). He said: So a grave was dug for him and he was placed in his grave. And he did not mention washing.

The Third: [Authentic] From Abdullah bin Az-Zubayr regarding the story of Uhud and the martyrdom of Hanzalah bin Abi Amir, he said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Indeed, your companion is being washed by the angels, so ask his wife." She said: "He went out while he was *Junub* (ritually impure) when he heard the *Ha'i'ah*." 1 The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "That is why the angels washed him."

11- Shrouding the Deceased.

33 - After finishing washing the deceased, it is obligatory to shroud him due to the command of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) regarding that in the Hadith of the *Muhrim* whose she-camel broke his neck: "...and shroud him..." the Hadith. It has been presented in full in Chapter 3, paragraph D.

34 - The shroud or its price must be from the wealth of the deceased, even if he left nothing else, due to the Hadith of Khabbab bin Al-Aratt who said: [Authentic] We emigrated with the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in the path of Allah, seeking the Face of Allah, so our reward became due upon Allah. Among us were those who passed away and did not consume any of their reward; among them was Mus'ab bin Umair. He was killed on the day of Uhud and nothing was found for him - and in a narration: And he left nothing except a *Namirah* (woolen garment). When we placed it over his head, his feet appeared, and when we placed it over his feet, his head appeared. So the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Place it over what is next to his head - and in a narration: Cover his head with it - and put *Idhkhir* 1 on his feet." And among us are those whose fruit has ripened and he is harvesting it.

35 - The shroud should be sufficient and ample, covering his entire body, due to the Hadith of Jabir bin Abdullah (may Allah be pleased with him): That the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) gave a sermon one day and mentioned a man from his companions who passed away and was shrouded in an insufficient shroud and was buried at night. So the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) rebuked burying a man at night until he is prayed over, unless

text:
a person is compelled to do so. And the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "If one of you shrouds his brother, let him shroud him well if he is able." The scholars said: The meaning of shrouding well is its cleanliness, thickness, covering capability, and moderation. It does not mean extravagance, excessiveness in cost, or preciousness.

36 - If the shroud is too narrow for that and a full covering is not available, his head and what it covers of his body should be covered with it, and whatever remains exposed should have *Idhkhir* or other grass placed upon it, due to the Hadith of Khabbab bin Al-Aratt in the story of Mus'ab regarding his *Namirah* and his (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) saying: "Place it over what is next to his head - and in a narration: Cover his head with it - and put *Idhkhir* on his feet." This was presented fully in Issue 34.

37 - If shrouds are scarce and the dead are many, it is permissible to shroud a group of them in a single shroud by distributing it among them, and the one who knew the most Qur'an among them is placed first towards the Qiblah, due to the Hadith of Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: [Hasan/Good] When it was the day of Uhud, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) passed by Hamza bin Abdul-Muttalib, and he had been mutilated and disfigured. He said: "If it were not that Safiyyah would feel grief in her heart, I would have left him until the *Afiya* 1 ate him so that Allah would resurrect him from the bellies of birds and beasts." So he shrouded him in a *Namirah*. When she covered his head, his feet appeared, and when she covered his feet, his head appeared, so she covered his head. He did not pray over anyone among the martyrs other than him and said: "I am a witness over you today." He said: The dead were many and the clothes were few. He said: So three and two were gathered

text:
in one grave, and he would ask which of them knew more Qur'an, so he would place him first in the *Lahd* (niche). And two or three men were shrouded in a single cloth. 1

38 - It is not permissible to remove the clothes of the martyr in which he was killed; rather, he is buried while they are on him, due to his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) regarding the slain of Uhud: "Wrap them in their clothes."

39 - It is recommended to shroud him with one garment or more over his clothes, as the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) did with Mus'ab bin Umair. His Hadith was presented in Issue 34.

40 - The *Muhrim* is shrouded in his two garments in which he died, due to his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) regarding the *Muhrim* whose she-camel broke his neck: "...and shroud him in his two garments in which he entered Ihram." This was presented fully in Chapter 3, paragraph D.

41 - Several things are recommended regarding the shroud:
First: Whiteness, due to his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): "Wear white from your clothes, for they are the best of your clothes, and shroud your dead in them."
Second: That it be three cloths, due to the Hadith of Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was shrouded in three white Yamani *Sahuliyah* cloths of cotton, there was no shirt among them nor a turban; he was wrapped in them in layers.
foot_note: 1. 1 Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah (may Allah have mercy on him) said: The meaning of the Hadith is that he used to divide the single cloth among the group, so each one would be shrouded with a part of it due to necessity, even if it only covered part of his body. The entirety of the Hadith indicates this, as he used to ask about the one who knew the most Qur'an to place him first in the *Lahd*. If they were all in one cloth collectively, he would have asked about the best of them before that so as not to lead to undoing the shrouding and repeating it. Mentioned in 'Awn al-Ma'bud 3/165. This interpretation is the correct one. As for the opinion of those who interpreted it literally, it is incorrect and contrary to the context of the story as explained by Ibn Taymiyyah. Even further from correctness is the one who said: "one cloth" means "one grave," because this is explicitly mentioned in the Hadith, so there is no meaning in repeating it.

Third: That one of them be a *Hibara* garment 1 if available, due to his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): "If one of you dies and finds something, let him be shrouded in a *Hibara* garment."
Fourth: [Authentic] Incensing it three times, due to his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): "If you incense the deceased, incense him three times." This ruling does not include the *Muhrim*, due to his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) regarding the *Muhrim* whose she-camel broke his neck: "...and do not perfume him..."

42 - It is not permissible to be extravagant in the shroud nor to exceed three (cloths), because it is contrary to what the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was shrouded in, as presented in the previous issue. It also involves wasting money, which is prohibited, especially since the living have more right to it. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Indeed, Allah disliked three things for you: Gossip ('it was said and he said'), wasting money, and asking too many questions."
I am pleased on this occasion by what the scholar Abu At-Tayyib said in Ar-Rawdah An-Nadiyyah 1/165: "Increasing the shrouds and being extravagant in their prices is not praiseworthy. Were it not for the Sharia mentioning it, it would have been a waste of money because the deceased does not benefit from it, nor does its benefit return to the living. May Allah have mercy on Abu Bakr As-Siddiq, as he said: 'The living has more right to the new,' when he was spoken to regarding his designation of one of his old garments for his shroud: 'This is worn out.'"

43 - The woman in this regard is like the man, as there is no evidence for differentiation.

12- Carrying the Funeral and Following It.

44 - It is obligatory to carry the funeral and follow it; this is among the rights of a Muslim upon Muslims. There are Hadiths regarding this, of which I mention two:
The First: [Authentic] His saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): "The rights of a Muslim upon a Muslim - and in a narration: Duties of a Muslim to his brother - are five: Returning the greeting (Salam), visiting the sick, following funerals, accepting invitations, and replying to the sneezer (Tashmeet)."
The Second: His saying also: "Visit the sick and follow funerals; they remind you of the Hereafter."

45 - Following it is of two levels:
The First: Following it from its family's house until the prayer over it.
The Other: Following it from its family's house until the completion of its burial.
Both of these were done by the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri (may Allah be pleased with him) narrated saying: [Authentic] When the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) arrived - meaning in Medina - if a dead person among us was present, we would notify the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), so he would attend, seek forgiveness for him until he passed away. Then the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and those with him would depart until he was buried. Sometimes this confinement would be prolonged for the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). So when we feared the hardship of that upon him, some of the people said to others: 'If only we would not notify the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) about anyone until he has passed away. Once he passes away, we notify him, so there would be no hardship or confinement upon him in that.' So we did that. We would notify him of the deceased after he died, so he would come and pray over him. Sometimes he would leave, and sometimes he would stay until the deceased was buried. We were upon that for a while. Then we said: 'If the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) did not travel (come out) and we carried our funeral to him so he could pray over it at his house, that would be easier for him.' So that became the practice until today.

46 - There is no doubt that the second level is better than the first, due to his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): "Whoever attends the funeral from its house - and in a narration: Whoever follows the funeral of a Muslim out of faith

and seeking reward until he prays over it, he will have a *Qirat*. And whoever attends it until it is buried - and in another narration: until it is finished - he will have two *Qirats* of reward." It was said: "O Messenger of Allah, what are the two *Qirats*?" He said: "Like two great mountains." In another narration: "Every *Qirat* is like Uhud."

47 - This merit in following funerals is specifically for men excluding women, due to the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) prohibiting women from following them. It is a prohibition of discouragement (Tanzeeh). Umm Atiyyah (may Allah be pleased with her) said: [Authentic] "We were forbidden - and in a narration: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) forbade us - from following funerals, but it was not strictly enforced upon us."

48 - It is not permissible to follow funerals with anything that contradicts the Sharia. Two things have been specifically mentioned in texts: Raising the voice in weeping and following it with incense (fire). That is in his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): "Do not follow the funeral with voice nor fire."

49 - Attached to this is raising the voice with *Dhikr* (remembrance) in front of the funeral, because it is an innovation (*Bid'ah*), and due to the saying of Qais bin Abbad: "The Companions of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to dislike raising the voice near funerals." Also because it involves imitating the Christians, for they raise their voices with things from their gospels and remembrances with elongation, melodic intonation, and sadness. Even uglier than that is accompanying it with playing musical instruments in front of it, playing sorrowful tunes, as is done in some Islamic lands in imitation of the disbelievers. And Allah is the One sought for help.
Al-Nawawi (may Allah have mercy on him) said in *Al-Adhkar* p. 203: "Know that the correct and chosen way, and what the Salaf (may Allah be pleased with them) were upon, is silence while walking with the funeral. No voice should be raised with recitation, *Dhikr*, or anything else. The wisdom in this is apparent: it is more calming for his heart and more conducive to gathering his thoughts regarding the funeral, which is what is required in this situation. This is the truth; do not be deceived by the large number of those who oppose it. Abu Ali Al-Fudayl

bin Iyad (may Allah be pleased with him) said words to the effect: 'Stick to the paths of guidance, and the small number of those walking them will not harm you. And beware of the paths of misguidance, and do not be deceived by the large number of those perishing.' We have narrated in *Sunan Al-Bayhaqi* what supports what I said - referring to the saying of Qais bin Abbad. As for what the ignorant do of recitation over the funeral in Damascus and elsewhere, reciting with elongation and taking words out of their places (intonation), it is forbidden (*Haram*) by consensus of the scholars. I have clarified its ugliness, the severity of its prohibition, and the sinfulness of whoever is able to denounce it but does not, in the book *Adab Al-Qira'ah* (Etiquettes of Recitation). And Allah is the One sought for help."

50 - It is obligatory to hasten in walking with it, a pace less than running (*Raml*), due to his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): "Hasten with the funeral. For if it is righteous, it is good you are advancing it to; and if it is other than that, it is an evil you are putting down from your necks."
I say: The apparent meaning of the command implies obligation, and Ibn Hazm held this view (5/154-155). We did not find evidence diverting it to recommendation, so we stopped at that. Ibn Al-Qayyim said in *Zad Al-Ma'ad*: "As for the creeping of people today, step by step, it is a disliked innovation, contrary to the Sunnah, and implies imitation of the People of the Book: the Jews."

51 - It is permissible to walk in front of it, behind it, to its right, and to its left, provided one is close to it, except for the rider who travels behind it, due to his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): "The rider travels behind the funeral, and the walker wherever he wishes around it: behind it, in front of it, to its right, and to its left, close to it. The child is prayed over, and forgiveness and mercy are supplicated for his parents."

52 - Both walking in front of it and behind it are established from the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in action, as Anas bin Malik (may Allah be pleased with him) said: "That the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), Abu Bakr, and Umar used to walk in front of the funeral and behind it."

53 - However, walking behind it is better because it is the implication of his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): "And follow the funerals," and meanings similar to it. This is supported by the saying of Ali (may Allah be pleased with him):

"Walking behind it is better than walking in front of it, like the superiority of a man's prayer in congregation over his prayer alone."

54 - Riding is permissible provided one travels behind it, due to his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in the previous Hadith: "The rider travels behind the funeral..." However, walking is better because it is what is customary from him (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), and it is not reported that he rode with it. Rather, Thawban (may Allah be pleased with him) said: An animal was brought to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) while he was with the funeral, but he refused to ride it. When he departed, the animal was brought and he rode. He was asked about it? He said: "Indeed the angels were walking, so I was not going to ride while they were walking. When they left, I rode."

55 - As for riding after departing from it, it is permissible without dislike, due to the Hadith of Thawban mentioned just now. Similar to it is the Hadith of Jabir bin Samurah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) prayed over Ibn Al-Dahdah and we were present - and in a narration: He went out to the funeral of Ibn Al-Dahdah walking, then a bare horse (without saddle) was brought, and a man tied it. He rode it when he departed, and it began to prance 1 with him while we followed running behind him - and in a narration: around him. He said: A man from the people said: The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "How many a hanging or drooping bunch of dates in Paradise is for Ibn Al-Dahdah."

56 - As for carrying the funeral on a cart or a car designated for funerals and the followers following it while in cars, this form is not legislated at all, for several reasons:
First: It is from the customs of the disbelievers, and it is established in the Sharia that it is not permissible to imitate them in that. There are very many Hadiths regarding this which I have compiled and extracted in my book *The Veil of the Muslim Woman in the Book and the Sunnah*. Some are commands and encouragement to differ from them in
