their worships, attire, and habits, and some are from his action (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in differing from them in that. Whoever wishes to view them may refer to it.
Second: It is an innovation in worship, while opposing the practical Sunnah in carrying the funeral. Anything of this sort among newly invented matters is misguidance by agreement.
Third: It misses the purpose of carrying and following it, which is remembering the Hereafter, as explicitly stated by the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in the Hadith mentioned at the beginning of this chapter with the wording: "...and follow funerals; they remind you of the Hereafter."
I say: Following it in that form causes people to miss this noble objective completely or partially. It is not hidden to the insightful person that carrying the deceased on shoulders and seeing the followers with it above their heads is more effective in realizing remembrance and admonition than following it in the mentioned form. I would not be exaggerating if I said: What drove the Europeans to this is only their fear of death and everything that reminds of it, due to the dominance of materialism over them and their disbelief in the Hereafter.
Fourth: It is a strong cause for reducing the number of those following it and those desiring to obtain the reward mentioned previously in Issue 46 of this chapter, because not everyone can hire a car to follow it.
Fifth: This form does not agree, remotely or closely, with what the pure, tolerant Sharia is known for regarding distance from formalities and protocols, especially in such a serious matter: Death. Truly I say: Even if this innovation had nothing but this violation, that would be enough to reject it. How then, when combined with the violations and corruptions previously explained and other things I have not mentioned?

57 - Standing for it is abrogated. It is of two types:
A - Standing of the seated person if it passes by him.

B - And the standing of the one following it when it reaches the grave until it is placed on the ground.
The evidence for this is the Hadith of Ali (may Allah be pleased with him): The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) stood for the funeral so we stood, then he sat so we sat. In a wording: He used to stand for funerals then he sat afterwards. In another: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to order us to stand for the funeral, then he sat after that and ordered us to sit.
It is recommended for whoever carried it to perform Wudu (ablution), due to his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): "Whoever washes a dead person, let him perform Ghusl, and whoever carries him, let him perform Wudu."

13- The Prayer Over the Funeral (Janazah).

58 - The prayer over the Muslim deceased is a communal obligation (*Fard Kifaya*) due to his command (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) for it in Hadiths. I mention among them the Hadith of Zaid bin Khalid Al-Juhani: [Authentic] That a man from the companions of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) died on the day of Khaibar. They mentioned that to the Messenger of Allah, so he said: "Pray over your companion." The faces of the people changed at that. He said: "Indeed your companion stole from the spoils (*Ghulul*) in the path of Allah." So we searched his belongings and found beads from the beads of the Jews not worth two dirhams.

59 - Two persons are exempted from that, so prayer over them is not obligatory:
The First: The child who has not reached puberty, because the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) did not pray over his son Ibrahim (peace be upon him). Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) said: Ibrahim, the son of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), died while he was eighteen months old, and the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) did not pray over him.
The Second: The martyr, because the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) did not pray over the martyrs of Uhud and others as preceded. However, this does not negate the legitimacy of praying over them without obligation, as will come in the following issue.

60 - Prayer is legislated over those mentioned below:
The First: The child, even if it was a miscarriage (*Siqt*), which is what falls from its mother's womb before completion, due to his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in the Hadith preceding in Issue 51: "...and the child - and in a narration: The miscarriage - is prayed over, and forgiveness and mercy are supplicated for his parents."
It appears that the miscarriage is only prayed over if the soul has been breathed into it. That is if it has completed four months then died. As for if it fell before that, then no,

because it is not a 'dead person' (Mayyit) as is obvious. The basis for that is the Hadith of Abdullah bin Masud (may Allah be pleased with him) raised to the Prophet: "Indeed the creation of one of you is gathered in his mother's womb for forty days, then it is a clot (*alaqa*) like that, then it is a lump of flesh (*mudgha*) like that, then Allah sends an angel to it... who breathes the soul into it."

The Second: The Martyr. There are many Hadiths regarding this; I suffice with mentioning some of them:
1 - [Hasan] From Abdullah bin Az-Zubayr: That the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) ordered Hamza on the day of Uhud (to be brought), so he was covered with a cloak, then he prayed over him and said nine Takbirs. Then the slain were brought, lined up, and he prayed over them and over him (Hamza) with them.
2 - From Uqbah bin Amir Al-Juhani: That the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) went out one day and prayed over the people of Uhud his prayer over the dead after eight years, like one bidding farewell to the living and the dead. Then he departed to the pulpit, praised Allah and extolled Him, then said: "I am a predecessor for you, and I am a witness over you. Indeed your appointment is at the Basin (*Al-Hwadh*), and by Allah, I am looking at my Basin right now. Its width is like what is between Ayla and Juhfa. I have been given the keys to the treasures of the earth - or the keys of the earth - and by Allah, I do not fear for you that you will associate partners with Allah after me, but I fear for you the world, that you will compete in it and fight each other, and thus perish as those before you perished." He said: That was the last look I cast at the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him).

The Third: One killed in a *Hadd* (legal punishment) of Allah's limits, due to the Hadith of 'Amir bin Husain: That a woman from Juhaynah came to the Prophet of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) while she was pregnant from adultery. She said: "O Prophet of Allah, I have committed an offense warranting a *Hadd*, so execute it upon me." The Prophet of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) called her guardian and said: "Treat her well, and when she delivers, bring her to me." So he did. Then the Prophet of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) ordered regarding her, so her clothes were tied upon her, then he ordered regarding her and she was stoned. Then he prayed over her. Umar said to him: "Do you pray

over her, O Prophet of Allah, when she has committed adultery?" He said: "She has repented a repentance that if divided among seventy of the people of Medina, it would suffice them. And have you found a repentance better than her sacrificing herself to Allah the Exalted?"

The Fourth: The immoral person immersed in sins and prohibitions, such as the abandoner of prayer and Zakat (while acknowledging their obligation), the adulterer, the addict of alcohol, and similar sinners. They are prayed over, except that it is appropriate for the people of knowledge and religion to leave praying over them as a punishment and a discipline for the likes of them, as the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) did. Regarding that are Hadiths, I mention one of them: From Abu Qatada who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to ask about a funeral if he was invited to it. If it was praised with good, he stood and prayed over it. If it was praised with other than that, he said to its family: "It is your affair with it," and he did not pray over it.

The Fifth: The debtor who did not leave enough wealth to pay off his debt. He is prayed over. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) only refrained from praying over him in the beginning of the matter. Regarding this are Hadiths:
1 - From Salamah bin Al-Akwa who said: We were sitting with the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) when a funeral was brought. They said: "Pray over it." He said: "Does he have any debt?" They said: "No." He said: "Did he leave anything?" They said: "No." So he prayed over him. Then another funeral was brought and they said: "O Messenger of Allah, pray over it." He said: "Does he have any debt?" It was said: "Yes." He said: "Did he leave anything?" They said: "Three dinars." He said: So he pointed with his fingers: three brands (count). So he prayed over him. Then a third was brought and they said: "Pray over him." He said: "Did he leave anything?" They said: "No." He said: "Does he have any debt?" They said: "Three dinars." He said: "Pray over your companion." A man from the Ansar called Abu Qatada said: "Pray over him, O Messenger of Allah, and his debt is upon me."
2 - From Abu Huraira: That the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to have a deceased man with debt brought to him. He would ask: "Did he leave any payment?" If he was told that he left enough to pay, he prayed over him; otherwise, he did not. He said: "Pray over

your companion." When Allah granted him conquests, he said: "I am closer to the believers than their own selves in this world and the Hereafter. Read if you wish: {The Prophet is closer to the believers than their own selves}. So whoever dies leaving a debt and did not leave payment, its repayment is upon me. And whoever leaves wealth, it is for his heirs."

The Sixth: The one who was buried before being prayed over, or whom some prayed over but not others. They pray over him while he is in his grave, provided that the Imam in the second case is one of those who had not prayed over him. Regarding that are Hadiths; I suffice here with one of them: From Abdullah bin Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: [Authentic] A man died - and the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to visit him (when sick) - so they buried him at night. When morning came, they informed him. He said: "What prevented you from informing me?" They said: "It was night and darkness, so we disliked causing you hardship." So he came to his grave and prayed over him. He said: He led us, and we lined up behind him, and I was among them, and he said four Takbirs.

The Seventh: Whoever dies in a land where there is no one to pray the prayer of the present (*Salat al-Hadir*) over him. A group of Muslims prays the absentee prayer (*Salat al-Gha'ib*) over him, due to the prayer of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) over An-Najashi (The Negus). A group of his companions (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) narrated it, some adding to others. I have gathered their Hadiths regarding it and presented them in one context approximately for benefit. The context is for the Hadith of Abu Huraira: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) announced the death of An-Najashi, Ashamah, the ruler of Abyssinia, to the people while he was in Medina on the day he died. He said: "Indeed a brother of yours has died - and in a narration: Today a righteous slave of Allah has died in a land other than yours - so stand and pray over him." They said: "Who is he?" He said: "An-Najashi." And he said: "Seek forgiveness for your brother." He said: So he went out with them to the Musalla (prayer place) - and in a narration: Al-Baqi' - then he stepped forward and they lined up behind him in two rows. He said: So we lined up behind him as one lines up for the dead, and we prayed over him as one prays over the dead, and we did not think but that the funeral was placed in front of him. He said: So he led us and prayed over him and said four Takbirs over him. It was said: "O Messenger of Allah, do you pray over

an Abyssinian slave?" So Allah Mighty and Majestic revealed: {And indeed, among the People of the Scripture are those who believe in Allah...} the Verse.
Ibn Al-Qayyim (may Allah have mercy on him) said in *Zad Al-Ma'ad* 1/205/206: "It was not of his guidance (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and Sunnah to pray over every absent dead person. Many people died among the Muslims while absent, and he did not pray over them. But it is authentic that he prayed over An-Najashi the prayer over the dead."
What supports the lack of legitimacy of praying over every absentee is that when the Rightly Guided Caliphs and others died, none of the Muslims prayed the absentee prayer over them. Had they done so, the report of it would have been widely transmitted (*Mutawatir*) from them. Compare this with what many Muslims do today of praying over every absentee, especially if he has fame or reputation, even if only politically, and is not known for righteousness or service to Islam, even if he died in the Meccan Sanctuary and thousands upon thousands prayed the present prayer over him during the Hajj season. Compare what we mentioned with such a prayer, and you will know with certainty that it is among the innovations about which a scholar of his Sunnah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and the way of the Salaf (may Allah be pleased with them) has no doubt.

61 - It is forbidden to pray over, seek forgiveness for, and ask mercy for disbelievers and hypocrites 1, due to the saying of Allah the Blessed and Exalted: {And do not pray [the funeral prayer, O Muhammad], over any of them who has died - ever - or stand at his grave. Indeed, they disbelieved in Allah and His Messenger and died while they were defiantly disobedient.}
And due to the Hadith of Ali (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: I heard a man seeking forgiveness for his parents while they were polytheists. I said: "Do you seek forgiveness for your parents while they are polytheists?" He said: "Did Ibrahim not seek forgiveness for his father while he was a polytheist?" He said: So I mentioned that

Their disbelief only becomes apparent through what filters out of their words of insinuations against some rulings of the Sharia and regarding them as ugly, and their claim that they are contrary to reason and taste. Our Lord, Blessed and Exalted, pointed to this reality in His saying: {Or do those in whose hearts is disease think that Allah would never expose their feelings of hatred? And if We willed, We could show them to you, and you would know them by their mark; but you will surely know them by the tone of [their] speech. And Allah knows your deeds.} Examples of these hypocrites are many in our era, and Allah is the One sought for help.

to the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), so it was revealed: {It is not for the Prophet and those who have believed to ask forgiveness for the polytheists, even if they were relatives, after it has become clear to them that they are companions of Hellfire. And the request of forgiveness of Abraham for his father was only because of a promise he had made to him. But when it became apparent to him that he was an enemy to Allah, he disassociated himself from him. Indeed was Abraham compassionate and patient.}
Al-Nawawi (may Allah have mercy on him) said in *Al-Majmu'* 5/144, 258: "Prayer over the disbeliever and supplicating for forgiveness for him is forbidden by the text of the Qur'an and Consensus."
I say: From that, you know the error of some Muslims today in asking for mercy and pleasure for some disbelievers. This occurs frequently from some newspaper and magazine owners. I heard one of the Arab leaders known for religiousness asking for mercy for the communist Stalin, who - along with his ideology - is among the fiercest and most bitter enemies of the religion. That was in a speech delivered by the mentioned leader on the occasion of the death of the aforementioned, broadcast on the radio. It is no wonder regarding this, for such a ruling might be hidden from him. But the wonder is from some Muslim preachers falling into the like of that, where one said in a letter of his: 'May Allah have mercy on Bernard Shaw...'
Some trustworthy people informed me about a Sheikh who used to pray over those who died from the Ismailis, despite his belief that they are not Muslims, because they do not believe in prayer nor Hajj and they worship humans. Yet, he used to pray over them out of hypocrisy and flattery to them. To Allah is the complaint, and He is the One sought for help.

62 - Congregation is obligatory in the funeral prayer just as it is obligatory in the prescribed prayers, due to two evidences:
The First: The perseverance of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) upon it.
The Other: His saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): "Pray as you have seen me praying."
What we mentioned is not disturbed by the prayer of the Companions over the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) individually without anyone leading them, because it is a special case whose reason is unknown. So it is not permissible to leave for its sake what he persevered upon

(peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) throughout his blessed life. Especially since the mentioned case was not reported with an authentic chain that stands as proof. Even if it was narrated through paths that strengthen each other, if it is possible to reconcile it with what we mentioned of his guidance (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in gathering for the funeral, then good; otherwise, his guidance is prioritized because it is more established and better guided. If they pray over it individually, the obligation drops, but they bear sin for leaving the congregation. And Allah knows best.
Al-Nawawi said in *Al-Majmu'* 5/314: "It is permissible to pray the funeral prayer individually without disagreement, but the Sunnah is that it be prayed in congregation due to the famous Hadiths in the 'Sahih' regarding that along with the consensus of the Muslims."

63 - The minimum number reported for the convening of congregation in it is three. In the Hadith of Abdullah bin Abi Talha: That Talha called the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) to Umair bin Abi Talha when he died. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) came to him and prayed over him in their house. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) stepped forward, Abu Talha was behind him, and Umm Sulaim was behind Abu Talha, and there was no one else with them.

64 - The larger the gathering, the better for the deceased and the more beneficial, due to his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): "There is no dead person whom a group of Muslims numbering one hundred prays over, all of them interceding for him, except that their intercession for him is accepted." And in another Hadith: "He is forgiven."
The deceased may be forgiven even if the number is less than one hundred, if they are Muslims whose Monotheism is not mixed with any Shirk (polytheism), due to his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): "There is no Muslim man who dies, and forty men who do not associate anything with Allah stand for his funeral prayer, except that Allah accepts their intercession for him."

65 - It is recommended that they line up behind the Imam in three rows or more, due to two Hadiths narrated regarding that. The issue is strengthened by their combination; check them in the original.

66 - If there is no one with the Imam except one man, he does not stand beside him as is the Sunnah in other prayers; rather, he stands behind the Imam, due to the Hadith preceding in Issue 63.

67 - The Ruler or his deputy has more right to the Imamate (leadership) in it than the guardian (family), due to the Hadith of Abu Hazim who said: "I was present the day Al-Hasan bin Ali died. I saw Al-Husain bin Ali saying to Sa'id bin Al-Aas, poking him in his neck and saying: 'Step forward; were it not a Sunnah, I would not have put you forward.'" Sa'id was the Amir of Medina on that day, and there was something between them.

68 - If the Ruler or his deputy is not present, then the one most entitled to Imamate is the one who knows the Book of Allah most, then according to the order mentioned in his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): "The people are led by the one who reads the Book of Allah most. If they are equal in reading, then the most knowledgeable of the Sunnah. If they are equal in the Sunnah, then the earliest in migration. If they are equal in migration, then the earliest in Islam. And a man should not lead a man in his authority, nor sit in his house on his place of honor except with his permission."
The one who reads most leads them even if he is a boy who has not reached puberty, due to the Hadith of Amr bin Salamah: That they - meaning his people - came as a delegation to the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). When they wanted to depart, they said: "O Messenger of Allah, who leads us?" He said: "The one of you with the most collection of the Qur'an or taking of the Qur'an." There was no one among the people who had collected what I had collected, so they put me forward while I was a boy wearing a cloak of mine. He said: "I did not attend a gathering of Jarm except that I was their Imam, and I pray over their funerals to this day."

69 - If multiple funerals of men and women gather, one prayer is prayed over them. The males - even if they are young - are placed closest to the Imam, and the funerals of the females closest to the Qiblah, for it is the Sunnah. As Nafi' said on the authority of Ibn Umar: That he prayed 1 over nine funerals together. He placed the men next to the Imam and the women next to the Qiblah, lining them up in one row. The funeral of Umm Kulthum bint Ali, the wife of Umar bin

Al-Khattab, and a son of hers called Zaid were placed together. The Imam that day was Sa'id bin Al-Aas, and among the people were Ibn Abbas, Abu Huraira, Abu Sa'id, and Abu Qatada. The boy was placed next to the Imam. A man said: So I denied that, and I looked at Ibn Abbas, Abu Huraira, Abu Sa'id, and Abu Qatada and said: "What is this?" They said: "It is the Sunnah."

70 - It is permissible to pray a prayer for each one of the funerals, because it is the default, and because the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) did that regarding the martyrs of Uhud as preceded in Issue 60/1.

71 - Praying over the funeral in the mosque is permissible, due to the Hadith of Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) who said: [Authentic] When Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas died, the wives of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) sent word to pass his funeral through the mosque so they could pray over him. So they did, and he was stopped at their apartments so they could pray over him. He was taken out through the Bab Al-Jana'iz (Funerals Door) which was towards the *Maqa'id* (sitting places). They were informed that the people criticized that and said: "This is an innovation; funerals were not entered into the mosque." That reached Aisha, so she said: "How quick are people to criticize what they have no knowledge of! They criticized us for passing a funeral through the mosque. By Allah, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) did not pray over Suhail bin Bayda and his brother except inside the mosque."

72 - However, it is better to pray over it outside the mosque in a place prepared for praying over funerals, as was the case during the time of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), and it is the dominant practice of his guidance regarding it. Regarding that are Hadiths mentioned in the original, among them his prayer (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) over An-Najashi in the Musalla near Al-Baqi' as preceded in Issue 60/7. And among them is the Hadith: That the Jews came to the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) with a man from them and a woman who committed adultery. He ordered regarding them, and they were stoned near the place of funerals by the mosque.

Al-Hafiz said in *Al-Fath*: The Musalla of funerals was adjacent to the Prophet's Mosque (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) from the east side. He said in another place (12-108): The Musalla where Eid and funerals were prayed is from the direction of Baqi' Al-Gharqad.

73 - It is not permissible to pray over it between the graves, due to the Hadith of Anas bin Malik (may Allah be pleased with him): That the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) forbade praying over funerals between the graves. And from him also: "He used to dislike that a mosque be built between graves." The Hadith is supported by what is *Mutawatir* (mass transmitted) from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) regarding the prohibition of taking graves as mosques. I mentioned what was reported regarding that in the beginning of my book *Tahdheer As-Sajid min Ittikhadh Al-Qubur Masajid* (Warning the Prostrator against Taking Graves as Mosques), and I will mention some of it in Issue 126, paragraph 9.

74 - The Imam stands behind the head of the man and the middle of the woman. There are two Hadiths regarding this; the most comprehensive is the Hadith of Abu Ghalib Al-Khayyat who said: [Authentic] I witnessed Anas bin Malik pray over the funeral of a man, so he stood at his head - and in a narration: the head of the bier. When it was lifted, the funeral of a woman from Quraish or the Ansar was brought. It was said to him: "O Abu Hamza, this is the funeral of so-and-so, daughter of so-and-so, pray over her." So he prayed over her and stood in her middle - and in a narration: at her buttocks - and upon her was a green coffin. Among us was Al-Ala bin Ziyad Al-Adawi 1. When he saw the difference in his standing for the man and the woman, he said: "O Abu Hamza, is this how the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to stand where you stood, and for the woman where you stood?" He said: "Yes." He said: So Al-Ala turned to us and said: "Memorize."
foot_note: 1. 1 His Kunya is Abu Nasr. He is among the trustworthy Tabi'in and was among the worshippers and reciters of the people of Basra. He died in the year ninety-four.

Description of the Funeral Prayer.

75 - He says Takbir over it four, or five, up to nine times. All of that is established from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). Whichever he does is sufficient. It is better to vary, doing this sometimes and that sometimes, as is the case in similar matters like the opening supplications, the forms of Tashahhud, the Abrahamic prayers, and the like. If one must adhere to one type, then it is four, because the Hadiths regarding it are stronger and more numerous. The follower says Takbir as the Imam says Takbir. The explanation of that is in the original.

76 - It is legislated for him to raise his hands in the first Takbir. There are two Hadiths regarding it, one strengthening the other, along with the consensus of the scholars upon it.

77 - Then he places his right hand over the back of his left palm, the wrist, and the forearm, then he tightens them on his chest. Regarding that are well-known Hadiths; you can see some of them in the original. As for placing them below the navel, it is weak by agreement, as stated by Al-Nawawi, Al-Zayla'i, and others.

78 - Then he recites after the first Takbir *Fatihat Al-Kitab* (The Opening of the Book) and a Surah, due to the Hadith of Talha bin Abdullah bin Awf who said: [Authentic] I prayed behind Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with him) over a funeral, so he read *Fatihat Al-Kitab* and a Surah, and he recited loudly until he made us hear. When he finished, I took his hand and asked him? He said: "I only recited loudly so you would know that it is a Sunnah and a right (truth)."

79 - And he recites silently, due to the Hadith of Abu Umamah bin Sahl who said: [Authentic] The Sunnah in the prayer over the funeral is to read in the first Takbir *Umm Al-Qur'an* (The Mother of the Quran) silently, then say Takbir three times, and the Taslim (salutation) is at the last one.

80 - Then he says the second Takbir and sends blessings upon the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), due to the mentioned Hadith of Abu Umamah that a man from the companions of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) told him: That the Sunnah in the prayer over the funeral is for the Imam to say Takbir, then read *Fatihat Al-Kitab* after

the first Takbir silently to himself, then send blessings upon the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), and sincerely supplicate for the funeral in the three Takbirs, not reading in any of them 1, then say Taslim silently to himself when he turns to his right. The Sunnah is for the one behind him to do the same as his Imam did. As for the formula of sending blessings upon the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in the funeral, I have not come across it in any of the authentic Hadiths. It appears that the funeral does not have a specific formula; rather, one uses one of the formulas established in the Tashahhud of the prescribed prayer 2.

81 - Then he performs the rest of the Takbirs and sincerely supplicates in them for the deceased, due to the Hadith of Abu Umamah mentioned just now and his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): "If you pray over the deceased, then be sincere in supplication for him." 3

82 - He supplicates in it with what is established from him (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) of supplications. I have found four of them:
First: "O Allah, forgive him and have mercy on him, give him well-being and pardon him, honor his reception and expand his entrance, wash him with water, snow, and hail, and cleanse him from sins as You cleansed - and in a narration: as the white garment is cleansed - of dirt. Exchange his home for a better home, his family for a better family, and his spouse - and in a narration: wife - for a better spouse. Admit him into Paradise and protect him from the punishment of the grave and from the punishment of the Fire."
foot_note:
1. 1 Meaning from the Qur'an, so it does not contradict reciting the supplications established in them as will come shortly, Allah willing.
2. 2 They are seven formulas I presented in *Description of the Prophet's Prayer*. The Islamic Office has printed it several times, the last being the ninth edition.
3. 3 Al-Sindi said: Meaning single him out with supplication. Al-Munawi said: Meaning supplicate for him with sincerity and presence of heart, because the purpose of this prayer is seeking forgiveness and intercession for the deceased. Acceptance is only hoped for when sincerity and supplication are present. Therefore, supplication is legislated in the prayer over him that is not legislated similarly in supplication for the living. Ibn Al-Qayyim said: This invalidates the saying of those who claim that the dead do not benefit from the supplication of the living. I say: In the narration of Al-Hakim from the Hadith of Abu Umamah mentioned previously: "And he makes the prayer sincere in the three Takbirs." Prayer (*Salah*) here means Supplication (*Dua*), evidenced by the first narration "and makes the Dua sincere," because the original meaning of Salah in the language is Dua. Among the strange interpretations is what is in *Al-Qawl Al-Badi'* p. 152: "And he makes the prayer sincere" meaning he raises his voice in his prayer with the three Takbirs.

text:
Second: "O Allah, forgive our living and our dead, our present and our absent, our young and our old, our males and our females. O Allah, whomever You keep alive among us, keep him alive on Islam, and whomever You cause to die among us, cause him to die on Faith. O Allah, do not deprive us of his reward and do not lead us astray after him."
Third: "O Allah, indeed so-and-so son of so-and-so is under Your protection and the rope of Your security, so save him from the trial of the grave and the punishment of the Fire. You are the Possessor of faithfulness and truth, so forgive him and have mercy on him. Indeed You are the Forgiving, the Merciful."
Fourth: "O Allah, Your slave and the son of Your bondswoman needed Your mercy, and You are free of need for his punishment. If he was a doer of good, then increase his good deeds, and if he was a wrongdoer, then overlook him." Then he supplicates whatever Allah wills him to supplicate.

83 - Supplication between the last Takbir and the Taslim is legislated, due to the Hadith of Abu Ya'fur from Abdullah bin Abi Awfa (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: I witnessed him and he said Takbir over a funeral four times, then he stood for a while - meaning - supplicating. Then he said: "Did you think I would say Takbir five times?" They said: "No." He said: "Indeed the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to say Takbir four times."

84 - Then he says two Taslims like his Taslim in the prescribed prayer, one to his right and the other to his left, due to the Hadith of Abdullah bin Masud (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: "Three practices the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to do which people have abandoned: One of them is Taslim over the funeral like the Taslim in prayer." It is established in Sahih Muslim and others from Ibn Masud that the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to say two Taslims in prayer. This clarifies that the intended meaning of his saying in the first Hadith "like the Taslim in prayer" is the two customary Taslims.

85 - It is permissible to restrict oneself to the first Taslim only, due to the Hadith of Abu Huraira (may Allah be pleased with him): That the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) prayed over a funeral, so he said Takbir over it four times and said one Taslim.

86 - The Sunnah is to say Taslim in the funeral silently; the Imam and those behind him are equal in that, due to the Hadith of Abu Umamah mentioned previously in Issue 80 with the wording: "Then he says Taslim silently to himself when he departs. The Sunnah is for the one behind him to do the same as his Imam did."

87 - It is not permissible to pray over the funeral in the three times during which prayer is forbidden unless out of necessity, due to the Hadith of Uqbah bin Amir (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: "Three hours the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to forbid us to pray in or bury our dead in: When the sun rises appearing until it rises high, when the one standing at noon stands until the sun inclines, and when the sun leans towards setting until it sets." Its generality includes the prayer over the funeral, and this is what the Companions understood as I explained in the original.

14 - Burial and its Related Matters.

88 - It is obligatory to bury the dead even if he was a disbeliever. Regarding that are two Hadiths:
The First: From a group of the companions of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), among them Abu Talha Al-Ansari, and the context is his: That the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) ordered regarding twenty-four men from the leaders of Quraish on the day of Badr. They were dragged by their feet and thrown into a *Tawa* (pit) 1 from the pits of Badr, filthy and foul. Some were thrown onto others, except for Umayyah bin Khalaf, for he had swollen in his armor and filled it. So when they went to move him, he fell apart 2, so they left him and threw over him whatever earth and stones would cover him... the Hadith.

The Second: From Ali (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: When Abu Talib died, I came to the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and said: "Indeed your uncle, the misguided old man, has died; so who will bury him?" He said: "Go and bury him, then do not speak of anything until you come to me." He said: "He died a polytheist." He said: "Go and bury him." He said: So I buried him then came to him. He said: "Go and perform Ghusl then do not speak of anything until you come to me." He said: So I performed Ghusl then came to him. He said: So he supplicated for me with supplications that I would not be pleased to exchange for red and black camels. He said: And Ali used to perform Ghusl if he washed the dead.

89 - A Muslim is not buried with a disbeliever, nor a disbeliever with a Muslim. Rather, the Muslim is buried in the graveyards of the Muslims, and the disbeliever in the graveyards of the polytheists. Such was the order during the time of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and it has continued to our era. Among the evidences for that is the Hadith of Bashir bin Al-Khasasiyyah who said: While I was walking with the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), holding his hand, he said: "O Ibn Al-Khasasiyyah, what

1. 1 It is a well that was lined and reinforced with stones so it would hold and not collapse.
2. 2 Meaning he disintegrated and his parts separated.

text:
do you have to resent against Allah? 1 You are walking with the Messenger of Allah." He said: I think he said: Holding his hand. I said: "O Messenger of Allah, may my father and mother be sacrificed for you, I do not resent anything against Allah; Allah has done every good for me." So he came upon the graves of the polytheists and said: "These have missed much good" - and in a narration: "much good" three times. Then he came upon the graves of the Muslims and said: "These have attained much good" three times. While he was walking, a glance from him fell upon a man walking among the graves wearing sandals. He said: "O owner of the *Sabtiyyah* (tanned leather shoes), woe to you! Throw off your *Sabtiyyah*." He looked, and when the man recognized the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), he took off his sandals and threw them.
Indeed, what confirms this is the Wise Lawgiver's differentiation between what a believer says if he visits the graves of Muslims and what he says if he passes by the graveyards of disbelievers, as will be explained shortly in the section on visiting graves.

90 - The Sunnah is burial in the graveyard, because the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to bury the dead in the Baqi' graveyard, as reports of that are *Mutawatir* (mass transmitted). Some were presented in various occasions, the closest being the Hadith of Ibn Al-Khasasiyyah which I cited in the previous issue. It has not been reported from any of the Salaf that he was buried other than in a graveyard, except what is also *Mutawatir* that the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was buried in his chamber. That is among his specific characteristics (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), as indicated by the Hadith of Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her): She said: When the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) passed away, they differed regarding his burial. Abu Bakr said: I heard from the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) something I have not forgotten. He said: "Allah does not take a Prophet except in the place he loves to be buried in." So they buried him in the place of his bedding.
foot_note: 1. 1 He (peace be upon him) only said this to him because Bashir (may Allah be pleased with him) had shown some annoyance due to his distance from the land of his people. At-Tabarani narrated in Al-Kabir 1236 and Al-Awsat from Bashir himself saying: I came to the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and caught up with him at Al-Baqi'. I heard him say: "Peace be upon the people of the abodes of the believers," and my sandal strap broke. He said: "Mend your strap." I said: "O Messenger of Allah, my bachelorhood has been long and I am far from the abode of my people." He said: "O Bashir, do you not praise Allah who took you by your forelock from among Rabi'ah, a people who believe that were it not for them the earth would overturn with those on it?" Al-Haythami said in Al-Majma' 3/60: And its men are trustworthy. I say: There is some question in it.

text:
91 - Exempted from the above are those who died as martyrs in battle; they are buried in the places of their martyrdom and are not moved to the graveyards, due to the Hadith of Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) went out from Medina to the polytheists to fight them. My father Abdullah said: "O Jabir bin Abdullah, do not fail to be among the onlookers of the people of Medina until you know what our matter comes to. For by Allah, were it not that I leave daughters of mine behind me, I would have loved for you to be killed in front of me." He said: So while I was among the onlookers, my aunt came with my father and my uncle, balancing them on a camel. She entered Medina with them to bury them in our graveyards - when a man caught up calling out: "Indeed the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) orders you to return with the slain and bury them in their places of death where they were killed." So we returned with them and buried them where they were killed.

92 - Burial is not permissible in the following situations except for necessity:
A - Burial in the three times, due to the Hadith of Uqbah bin Amir preceded in Issue 87 with the wording: "Three hours the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to forbid us to pray in or bury our dead in..." the Hadith.
B - At night, due to the Hadith of Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him): "...So the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) rebuked burying a man at night until he is prayed over 1 unless a person is compelled to do so." It has preceded in full in Issue 35.

93 - If they are compelled to bury him at night, it is permissible even with the use of a lamp and descending with it into the grave to facilitate the burial process. The evidence is the Hadith of Ibn Abbas: "That the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) put a man into his grave at night and lit a lamp in his grave."
foot_note: 1. 1 Meaning during the day because it is a time likely to have a larger congregation.

text:
94 - It is obligatory to deepen the grave, widen it, and improve it. Regarding this are two Hadiths:
The First: From Hisham bin Amir who said: When it was the day of Uhud, those of the Muslims who were struck were struck, and injuries befell the people. We said: "O Messenger of Allah, digging for every person is difficult for us, so how do you command us?" He said: "Dig, widen, deepen, and improve. Bury two and three in a grave, and put forward the one who knew the most Qur'an. He said: My father was the third of three, and he knew the most Qur'an, so he was put forward."

The Second: From a man of the Ansar who said: We went out with the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in the funeral of a man from the Ansar. I was a boy with my father. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) sat at the hole of the grave and began instructing - and in a narration signaling to - the digger, saying: "Widen from the direction of the head, and widen from the direction of the feet. For many a hanging bunch of dates is for him in Paradise." 1

95 - *Lahd* (niche) 2 and *Shaqq* (trench) are permissible in the grave because practice proceeded upon both in the time of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), but the first (*Lahd*) is better. Regarding that are Hadiths; I mention two of them:
The First: From Anas bin Malik who said: When the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) passed away, there was a man in Medina who made *Lahd* and another who made *Darih* (Shaqq). They said: "We will seek guidance from our Lord and send for both of them; whichever arrives first, we will leave him (to do it)." So they sent for both, and the maker of the *Lahd* arrived first, so they made a *Lahd* for the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him).
foot_note:
1. 1 I say: The apparent meaning of the command in the two Hadiths implies the obligation of what was mentioned in them regarding deepening, widening, and improving. It is known from the Shafi'is and others that deepening is recommended. As for Ibn Hazm, he explicitly stated in Al-Muhalla 5/116 its obligation. They differed on the limit of deepening according to sayings you can see in Al-Majmu' or elsewhere.
2. 2 With Fatha on Lam and with Damma and Sukun on Ha; it is the excavation in the side of the grave from the direction of the Qiblah. The *Shaqq* is the *Darih*, which is to dig downwards like a river (trench).

text:
The Second: From Ibn Abbas that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "The *Lahd* is for us, and the *Shaqq* is for others."

96 - There is no harm in burying two or more in it in case of necessity, and the best of them is put forward. Regarding it are Hadiths; the Hadith of Anas in Issue 37 and the Hadith of Hisham bin Amir in Issue 100 94 have preceded.

97 - Men, not women, undertake lowering the deceased, even if it is a female, for several reasons:
First: It is the custom in the time of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and the practice of Muslims has continued upon it until today. The Hadith of Anas regarding it comes in Issue 99.
Second: Men are stronger for that.
Third: If women undertook it, it would lead to the exposure of part of their bodies before strangers, which is not permissible.

98 - The guardians (relatives) of the deceased have more right to lower him, due to the generality of His saying: {And those of [blood] relationship 1 are more entitled [to inheritance] in the decree of Allah.} And due to the Hadith of Ali (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: [Authentic] I washed the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and went to see what usually comes from the deceased, but I saw nothing. He was pure in life and in death. Four people undertook his burial and laying him in the grave excluding the people: Ali, Al-Abbas, Al-Fadl, and Salih the freed slave of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). A *Lahd* was made for the Messenger of Allah, and bricks were set up over him.
And from Abdur-Rahman bin Abza who said: I prayed with Umar bin Al-Khattab over Zainab bint Jahsh in Medina. He said Takbir four times, then sent word to the wives of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): "Who do you order to put her into the grave?" He said: And he liked to be the one to undertake that. So they sent word to him: "Look at who used to see her during her life; let him be the one to put her into the grave." So Umar said: "You have spoken the truth."
foot_note: 1. 1 They are the father and his fathers, the son and his sons, then full brothers, then those for the father, then their sons, then paternal uncles for father and mother, then for father, then their sons, then every Mahram relative. So in Al-Muhalla 5/143. And similar in Al-Majmu' 5/290.

text:
99 - It is permissible for the husband to undertake the burial of his wife himself, due to the Hadith of Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) entered upon me on the day following the one in which his illness began, and I said: "Oh my head!" He said: "I wish that had happened while I was alive, so I would prepare you and bury you." She said: So I said: Jealousy! It is as if I see you on that day as a bridegroom with one of your wives. He said: "Rather, I, oh my head! Call for me your father and your brother so I can write a writing for Abu Bakr, for I fear that a sayer will say or a wisher will wish: 'I am more entitled,' while Allah Mighty and Majestic and the believers refuse anyone except Abu Bakr."

100 - However, that is conditional upon him not having had intercourse that night; otherwise, it is not legislated for him to bury her, and someone else would be more entitled to bury her, even if a stranger, with the mentioned condition. Due to the Hadith of Anas bin Malik (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: We attended the funeral of a daughter of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), and the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was sitting by the grave. I saw his eyes tearing. Then he said: "Is there a man among you who did not commit intercourse (*Yuqarif*) with his family last night?" Abu Talha said: "Yes, I am, O Messenger of Allah." He said: "Then descend." He said: So he descended into her grave and buried her. 1

101 - The Sunnah is to insert the deceased from the rear (foot end) of the grave, due to the Hadith of Abu Ishaq who said: Al-Harith instructed in his will that Abdullah bin Yazid pray over him. So he prayed over him, then put him into the grave from the direction of the grave's feet and said: "This is from the Sunnah." And from Ibn Sirin who said: I was with Anas at a funeral, so he ordered concerning the deceased, so he was inserted from the direction of the feet of the grave.

This is one of many proofs that the Faqih cannot dispense with the books of Sunnah, contrary to what the fanatics of the Madhhabs think, that the books of Fiqh suffice instead of the books of Hadith, and even the Book of Allah, Blessed and Exalted, far above what the wrongdoers say. 102 - The deceased is placed in his grave on his right side, his face facing the Qiblah, and his head and feet to the right and left of the Qiblah. This has been the practice of the people of Islam from the time of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) to our day, and such is every graveyard on the face of the earth. Thus in Al-Muhalla 5/173 and others.

103 - The one who places him in his *Lahd* says: "In the name of Allah, and upon the Sunnah of the Messenger of Allah," or: "the Millah (religion) of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him)." Or he says: "In the name of Allah, and by Allah, and upon the Millah of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him)." He (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) commanded all of that.

104 - It is recommended for the one at the grave to throw three handfuls of dirt with both hands after finishing the closing of the *Lahd*, due to the Hadith of Abu Huraira: That the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) prayed over a funeral, then came to the deceased and threw earth upon him from the direction of his head three times.

105 - After finishing his burial, several things are Sunnah:
First: To raise the grave slightly above the ground, about a hand-span, and not to level it with the ground so it is distinguished, preserved, and not disrespected, due to the Hadith of Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him): That the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) had a *Lahd* made for him, bricks were set up over him, and his grave was raised from the ground about a hand-span.
Second: To make it mounded (*Musannam*), due to the Hadith of Sufyan At-Tammar who said: I saw the grave of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and the graves of Abu Bakr and Umar mounded.
Third: To mark it with a stone or the like so that his family members who die can be buried near him, due to the Hadith of Al-Muttalib bin Abi Wada'ah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: When Uthman bin Maz'un died, his funeral was taken out and he was buried. The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) ordered a man to

bring him a rock, but he was unable to carry it. So the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) went to it and rolled up his sleeves from his arms. Al-Muttalib said: The one who told me about the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: It is as if I am looking at the whiteness of the arms of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) when he uncovered them. Then he carried it and placed it at his head and said: "I mark with it the grave of my brother, and I bury near him whoever dies of my family."
Fourth: Not to instruct (*Talqin*) the deceased with the instruction known today, because the Hadith reported regarding it is not authentic. Rather, one stands at the grave supplicating for steadfastness for him and seeking forgiveness for him, and ordering those present to do so, due to the Hadith of Uthman bin Affan (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to, when he finished burying the deceased, stand over him and say: "Seek forgiveness for your brother and ask for steadfastness for him, for he is now being questioned."

106 - It is permissible to sit by him during the burial with the intention of reminding those present of death and what comes after it, due to the Hadith of Al-Bara' bin Azib. There is no harm in mentioning it at length due to what it contains of hope, fear, and admonition. He said: We went out with the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in a funeral of a man from the Ansar. We reached the grave and the niche had not yet been dug. So the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) sat facing the Qiblah, and we sat around him as if birds were on our heads. In his hand was a stick with which he was scratching the ground. He began looking at the ground and raising his gaze and lowering it three times. Then he said: "Seek refuge in Allah from the punishment of the grave" twice or thrice. Then he said: "O Allah, I seek refuge in You from the punishment of the grave" three times. Then he said: "Indeed, the believing servant, when he is in departure from this world and approach to the Hereafter, angels descend to him from the sky with white faces as if their faces were the sun, having with them a shroud from the shrouds of Paradise and perfume (*Hanoot*) from the perfume of Paradise, until they sit from him as far as the eye can see. Then the Angel of Death (peace be upon him) comes until he sits at his head and says: 'O good soul - and in a narration: reassured soul - come out to forgiveness from Allah and pleasure.' He said: So it comes out flowing as the drop flows from the mouth of the waterskin. So he takes it - and in a narration: until when his soul comes out, every angel between the sky and earth prays over it

and every angel in the sky. And the gates of the sky are opened for him; there are no people of a gate except that they supplicate to Allah that his soul ascend through them. When he (Angel of Death) takes it, they do not leave it in his hand for the blink of an eye until they take it and place it in that shroud and that perfume. That is His saying, Exalted is He: {Our messengers take him, and they do not fail.} And there comes out from it like the best scent of musk found on the face of the earth. He said: So they ascend with it, and they do not pass - meaning with it - by a group of angels except that they say: 'What is this good soul?' So they say: 'So-and-so son of So-and-so' with the best of his names by which they used to name him in the world, until they reach the lowest heaven with it. They ask for it to be opened, and it is opened for them. Those closest to Allah in every heaven accompany it to the heaven that follows it until it reaches the seventh heaven. So Allah Mighty and Majestic says: 'Write the book of My servant in *Illiyyin*. {And what can make you know what is Illiyyun? It is a register inscribed, Which is witnessed by those brought near.}' So his book is written in *Illiyyin*. Then He says: 'Return him to the earth, for I promised them that from it I created them, and into it I return them, and from it I extract them another time.' He said: So he is returned to the earth, and his soul is returned to his body. He said: Indeed, he hears the tapping of the sandals of his companions when they turn away from him departing. Then two angels with severe rebuke come to him, rebuke him, and make him sit. They say to him: 'Who is your Lord?' He says: 'My Lord is Allah.' They say to him: 'What is your religion?' He says: 'My religion is Islam.' They say to him: 'Who is this man who was sent among you?' He says: 'He is the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him).' They say to him: 'And what is your knowledge?' He says: 'I read the Book of Allah and believed in it and affirmed it.' So he rebukes him and says: 'Who is your Lord? What is your religion? Who is your Prophet?' And this is the last trial presented to the believer. That is when Allah Mighty and Majestic says: {Allah keeps firm those who believe, with the firm word, in worldly life}. So he says: 'My Lord is Allah, my religion is Islam, and my Prophet is Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him).' Then a caller calls from the sky: 'My servant has spoken the truth, so spread out for him from Paradise and clothe him from

Paradise, and open for him a door to Paradise.' He said: So its breeze and fragrance come to him, and his grave is expanded for him as far as his eye can see. He said: And in a narration: A man with a handsome face, handsome clothes, and good scent appears to him and says: 'Rejoice with what pleases you, rejoice with pleasure from Allah and gardens containing lasting bliss. This is your day which you were promised.' So he says to him: 'And you, may Allah give you glad tidings of good, who are you? For your face is the face that brings good.' So he says: 'I am your righteous deed. By Allah, I only knew you to be quick in the obedience of Allah, slow in the disobedience of Allah, so may Allah reward you with good.' Then a door from Paradise and a door from the Fire are opened for him, and it is said: 'This would have been your place had you disobeyed Allah; Allah has exchanged this for you.' When he sees what is in Paradise, he says: 'My Lord, hasten the establishment of the Hour so that I may return to my family and my wealth.' So it is said to him: 'Reside.' He said: And indeed the disbelieving servant - and in a narration: the wicked - when he is in departure from the world and approach to the Hereafter, angels descend to him from the sky, harsh and severe, with black faces, having with them *Masuh* (sackcloth) 1 from the Fire. They sit from him as far as the eye can see. Then the Angel of Death comes until he sits at his head and says: 'O foul soul, come out to anger from Allah and wrath.' He said: So it scatters throughout his body, and he pulls it out just as the multi-pronged skewer (*Saffud*) is pulled out of wet wool, tearing with it the veins and nerves. Every angel between the sky and earth and every angel in the sky curses him. The gates of the sky are closed; there are no people of a gate except that they supplicate to Allah that his soul not ascend through them. So he takes it. If he takes it, they do not leave it in his hand for the blink of an eye until they place it in that sackcloth. And there comes out from it like the foulest stench of a corpse found on the face of the earth. So they ascend with it, and they do not pass by a group of angels except that they say: 'What is this foul soul?' So they say: 'So-and-so son of So-and-so' - with the ugliest of his names by which he used to be called in the world, until they reach the lowest heaven with it. They ask for it to be opened for him, but it is not opened for him. Then the Messenger of Allah recited:
foot_note: 1. 1 Plural of *Mas-h* with Kasra on the Mim; it is what is worn of woven hair on the body for austerity and suppression of the body.

text: (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): {The gates of Heaven will not be opened for them, nor will they enter Paradise until a camel enters into the eye of a needle.} 1 So Allah Mighty and Majestic says: 'Write his book in *Sijjin* in the lowest earth.' Then it is said: 'Return My servant to the earth, for I promised them that from it I created them, and into it I return them, and from it I extract them another time.' So his soul is thrown from the sky, a throw until it falls into his body. Then he recited: {And he who associates with Allah - it is as though he had fallen from the sky and was snatched by the birds or the wind carried him down into a remote place.} So his soul is returned to his body. He said: Indeed he hears the tapping of the sandals of his companions when they turn away from him. Then two angels with severe rebuke come to him, rebuke him, and make him sit. They say to him: 'Who is your Lord?' He says: 'Haah, Haah 2, I do not know.' They say to him: 'What is your religion?' He says: 'Haah, Haah, I do not know.' They say to him: 'What do you say about this man who was sent among you?' He cannot find his name, so it is said: 'Muhammad.' He says: 'Haah, Haah, I do not know. I heard the people saying that.' He said: So it is said: 'You did not know nor did you recite.' Then a caller calls from the sky: 'He has lied, so spread out for him from the Fire, and open for him a door to the Fire.' So its heat and scorching wind come to him, and his grave tightens upon him until his ribs interlock. And there comes to him - and in a narration: there appears to him - a man with an ugly face, ugly clothes, and a foul stench who says: 'Receive tidings of what displeases you; this is your day which you were promised.' So he says: 'And you, may Allah give you tidings of evil, who are you? For your face is the face that brings evil.' He says: 'I am your foul deed. By Allah, I only knew you to be slow in the obedience of Allah, quick to the disobedience of Allah, so may Allah reward you with evil.' Then a blind, deaf, and mute (being) is appointed over him, in his hand a sledgehammer; if a mountain were struck with it, it would become dust. So he strikes him a blow until he becomes dust. Then Allah restores him as he was, and he strikes him another blow, so he screams a scream which everything hears
foot_note:
1. 1 Meaning the hole of the needle. The *Jamal* (camel) is the well-known animal, which is what has reached nine years of age.
2. 2 It is a word said in laughter and in threat, and it may be said for expressing pain, which is more fitting to the meaning of the Hadith. And Allah knows best. Thus in *At-Targhib*.

text:
except the *Thaqalayn* (men and jinn). Then a door from the Fire is opened for him, and bedding from the Fire is spread out. So he says: 'My Lord, do not establish the Hour.'

107 - It is permissible to exhume the deceased from the grave for a valid reason, such as if he was buried before being washed and shrouded and the like, due to the Hadith of Jabir bin Abdullah who said: [Authentic] The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) came to Abdullah bin Ubayy after he had been placed in his pit. He ordered regarding him, so he was taken out. He placed him on his knees, blew lightly (*nafatha*) upon him from his saliva, and clothed him in his shirt. Jabir said: And he prayed over him, so Allah knows best 1. And he had clothed Abbas in a shirt.

108 - It is not recommended for a man to dig his grave before he dies, for the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) did not do that, nor did his companions. The servant does not know where he will die. If the man's intention is preparation for death, then this is from righteous deeds. Thus in *Al-Ikhtiyarat Al-'Ilmiyyah* of Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah the Exalted have mercy on him.
foot_note: 1. 1 Meaning regarding the wisdom for why he (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) did that with Ibn Ubayy despite him being a hypocrite. It appears that this was before the revelation of the saying of the Exalted: {And do not pray [the funeral prayer, O Muhammad], over any of them who has died - ever - or stand at his grave} the Verse.

15- Condolences (*At-Ta'ziyah*).

109 - Consoling the family of the deceased is legislated 1. Regarding it are two Hadiths:
The First: From Qurrah Al-Muzani (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: [Authentic] The Prophet of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to, when he sat, have a group of his companions sit with him. Among them was a man who had a small son; he would come to him from behind his back and seat him in front of him. The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said to him: "Do you love him?" He said: "O Messenger of Allah, may Allah love you as I love him." Then he (the son) died. The man refrained from attending the circle due to the remembrance of his son, and he grieved for him. So the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) missed him and said: "Why do I not see so-and-so?" They said: "O Messenger of Allah, his son whom you saw has died." So the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) met him and asked him about his son? He informed him that he had died. So he offered him condolences for him, then said: "O so-and-so, which is more beloved to you: that you enjoy him for your lifespan, or that you do not come tomorrow to a gate from the gates of Paradise except that you find him having preceded you to it, opening it for you?" He said: "O Prophet of Allah, rather that he precedes me to the gate of Paradise and opens it for me is more beloved to me." He said: "Then that is for you." A man from the Ansar said: "O Messenger of Allah, may Allah make me your sacrifice, is it for him specifically or for all of us?" He said: "Rather, for all of you."

The Second: From Anas bin Malik (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) who said: "Whoever consoles his believing brother in his calamity, Allah will clothe him in a green garment of honor by which he will be delighted (*yuhbar*) on the Day of Judgment." It was said: "O Messenger of Allah, what is *yuhbar*?" He said: "He will be envied (in a good way/ *yughbat*)."
foot_note: 1. 1 It is urging patience by promising reward and supplicating for the deceased and the afflicted.

text:
110 - He should console them with what he thinks will comfort them, suppress their sadness, and encourage them to be content and patient, using what is established from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) if he knows and recalls it. Otherwise, with whatever good words are available to him that achieve the purpose and do not contradict the Sharia, such as their saying: 'May He give you his remaining lifespan' (A'taka Umrahu). Regarding this are Hadiths:
First: From Usama bin Zaid who said: One of the daughters of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) sent a message to him: That a son of hers - or a daughter, and in a narration Umaymah bint Zainab 1 - is dying, so witness us. He said: So he sent a messenger to her conveying the Salam and saying: 'Indeed, to Allah belongs what He took, and to Allah belongs what He gave, and everything with Him has a fixed term. So let her be patient and seek reward from Allah...' The Hadith.
I say: This wording of condolence, although reported regarding someone approaching death, using it for someone who has already died is more appropriate by indication of the text. For this reason, Al-Nawawi said in Al-Adhkar and elsewhere: 'This Hadith is the best form of condolence.'
Second: His saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) to the Ansari woman, consoling her for her son: 'It has reached me that you are grieving over your son,' so he commanded her to fear Allah and be patient. She said: 'O Messenger of Allah, why should I not grieve when I am a *Raqoob* woman (childless), I do not give birth, and I had none but him?' The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: 'The *Raqoob* is the one whose child survives (and she dies without sending one ahead).' Then he said: 'There is no Muslim man or woman whose three children die, and they seek reward from Allah for them, except that Allah will admit them into Paradise because of them.' Umar, who was to the right of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), said: 'May my father and mother be sacrificed for you, and two?' He said: 'And two.'
foot_note: 1. 1 I say: Then this Umaymah - also called Umamah - lived until Ali married her after Fatima (may Allah be pleased with them).

text:
Third: His saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) when he entered upon Umm Salamah (may Allah be pleased with her) following the death of Abu Salamah: 'O Allah, forgive Abu Salamah, raise his degree among the guided, grant him a successor in his descendants who remain behind, forgive us and him, O Lord of the worlds, make his grave spacious for him, and light it for him.' This has been presented in full in Issue 17.
Fourth: His saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in his condolence to Abdullah bin Ja'far regarding his father: 'O Allah, grant Ja'far a successor in his family, and bless Abdullah in the transaction of his right hand.' He said it three times. It comes in full in the following issue.

111 - Condolence is not limited to three days not to be exceeded; rather, whenever he sees a benefit in condolence, he should perform it. It is established from him (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) that he offered condolences after three days in the Hadith of Abdullah bin Ja'far (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) sent an army and appointed Zaid bin Harithah over them and said: 'If Zaid is killed or martyred, then your commander is Ja'far. If he is killed or martyred, then your commander is Abdullah bin Rawahah.' They met the enemy, so Zaid took the banner and fought until he was killed. Then Ja'far took the banner and fought until he was killed. Then Abdullah took it and fought until he was killed. Then Khalid bin Al-Walid took the banner and Allah granted him victory. The news of them came to the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), so he went out to the people, praised Allah and extolled Him, and said: 'Indeed, your brothers met the enemy. Zaid took the banner and fought until he was killed and martyred. Then... then... then the banner was taken by a sword from the swords of Allah, Khalid bin Al-Walid, and Allah granted him victory.'

So he waited, then gave the family of Ja'far three days respite to come to them. Then he came to them and said: 'Do not weep over my brother after this day. Call my nephews to me.' He said: So we were brought as if we were chicks. He said: 'Call the barber for me.' So the barber was brought and he shaved our heads. Then he said: 'As for Muhammad, he resembles our uncle Abu Talib. As for Abdullah, he resembles my physical creation and my character.' Then he took my hand and raised it and said: 'O Allah, grant Ja'far a successor in his family, and bless Abdullah in the transaction of his right hand.' He said it three times. He said: Then our mother came and mentioned our orphanhood to him and began to complain of grief 1 to him. He said: 'Are you afraid of poverty for them while I am their guardian in this world and the Hereafter?'

112 - Two things should be avoided, even if people follow them customarily:
A - Gathering for condolences in a specific place like a house, graveyard, or mosque.
B - The family of the deceased preparing food to host those coming for condolences.
This is due to the Hadith of Jarir bin Abdullah Al-Bajali (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: 'We used to consider - and in a narration: see - gathering with the family of the deceased and making food after his burial as part of wailing (Niyahah).'
Al-Nawawi said in Al-Majmu' 5/306: 'As for sitting for condolences, Al-Shafi'i, the author (Al-Shirazi), and all the companions (of the Shafi'i school) stated it is disliked (Makruh). They said: By sitting for it, they mean that the family of the deceased gathers in a house so that those who want to offer condolences come to them. They said: Rather, they should go about their needs, and whoever meets them consoles them. There is no difference between men and women in the dislike of sitting for it.'
The text of Imam Al-Shafi'i to which Al-Nawawi referred in Kitab Al-Umm 1/248 is:
foot_note: 1. 1 Meaning she causes him grief and sadness. Derived from 'Afraha': if he saddened him and removed joy from him. 'Afrahahu Ad-Dayn': Debt burdened him.

text:
'And I dislike *Al-Ma'atim* - which is the gathering (of people) - even if there is no crying, for that renews grief and imposes costs (burden), alongside what has passed in the narration regarding it.' It is as if he is referring to this Hadith of Jarir.
Al-Nawawi said: 'The author and others argued for it with another proof, which is that it is an innovation (Muhdath).'
Likewise, Ibn Al-Humam stated in Sharh Al-Hidayah 1/473 the dislike of the family of the deceased hosting a meal, and he said: 'It is an ugly innovation.' This is also the Madhhab of the Hanbalis as in Al-Insaf 2/565.

113 - The Sunnah is only that the relatives and neighbors of the deceased make food for the family of the deceased that satisfies them, due to the Hadith of Abdullah bin Ja'far (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: When the news of Ja'far's death came, the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: 'Make food for the family of Ja'far, for there has come to them a matter that occupies them - or has come to them what occupies them.'
Imam Al-Shafi'i said in Al-Umm 1/247: 'And I like for the neighbors of the deceased or his relatives to make for the family of the deceased on the day he dies and its night food that satisfies them, for that is a Sunnah and a noble memory, and it is from the actions of the people of goodness before us and after us.' Then he quoted the mentioned Hadith from Abdullah bin Ja'far.

114 - It is recommended to wipe the head of the orphan and honor him, due to the Hadith of Abdullah bin Ja'far who said: If you had seen me, Qutham, and Ubaidullah bin Abbas while we were young boys playing, when the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) passed by on a mount. He said: 'Lift this one to me.' He said: So he carried me in front of him. And he said to (concerning) Qutham: 'Lift this one to me,' so he carried him behind him. Ubaidullah was more beloved to Abbas than Qutham, so he did not feel shy from his uncle that he carried Qutham and left him. He said:

Then he wiped over my head three times and said each time he wiped: 'O Allah, grant Ja'far a successor in his son.' He said: I said to Abdullah: What happened to Qutham? He said: He was martyred. He said: I said: Allah and His Messenger know best about the good. He said: Yes.

What Benefits the Deceased.

115 - The deceased benefits from the action of others in several matters:
First: The supplication of a Muslim for him if the conditions of acceptance are met, due to the saying of Allah, Blessed and Exalted: {And those who came after them say: "Our Lord, forgive us and our brothers who preceded us in faith and put not in our hearts [any] resentment toward those who have believed. Our Lord, indeed You are Kind and Merciful."}
As for the Hadiths, they are very many; some have preceded and some will come in the section on visiting graves and the Prophet's supplication for them and his command to do so. Among them is his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): 'The supplication of a Muslim man for his brother in his absence is answered. At his head is an appointed angel; whenever he supplicates for his brother with good, the appointed angel says: Amen, and for you the same.' Indeed, the funeral prayer itself is largely evidence for this, because most of it is supplication for the deceased and seeking forgiveness for him, as previously explained.

Second: The guardian (Wali) of the deceased making up the fast of a vow (Nadhr) on his behalf. Regarding this are Hadiths:
The First: From Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: 'Whoever dies while having fasting due upon him, his guardian fasts on his behalf.' This is interpreted as referring to the fast of a vow, not the fast of Ramadan, and its explanation is in the original.
The Second: From Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with him): That a woman rode the sea and vowed that if Allah, Blessed and Exalted, saved her, she would fast

a month. Allah, Mighty and Majestic, saved her, but she did not fast until she died. A female relative of hers, either her sister or her daughter, came to the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and mentioned that to him. He said: 'Do you see that if she had a debt, you would pay it off?' She said: 'Yes.' He said: 'Then the debt of Allah has more right to be paid.' [So] 'Pay it (fast) on behalf of your mother.'

Third: Paying off the debt on his behalf by any person, whether a guardian or otherwise, as preceded.

Fourth: The righteous deeds performed by the righteous child, for the parents have a reward similar to his reward without diminishing anything from his reward, because the child is from their striving and earning. Allah, Mighty and Majestic, says: {And that there is not for man except that [good] for which he strives}. And the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: 'Indeed the best of what a man eats is from his earning, and indeed his child is from his earning.'
What the verse and Hadith indicate is supported by specific Hadiths reported regarding the parent benefiting from the deed of his righteous child, such as charity, fasting, freeing slaves, and the like. These are some of them:
The First: From Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her): That a man said: 'My mother passed away suddenly 1 and did not make a will. I think if she had spoken she would have given charity. Will she have a reward if I give charity on her behalf, and will I have a reward?' He said: 'Yes, give charity on her behalf.'
The Second: From Abdullah bin Umar: That Al-Aas bin Wa'il Al-Sahmi made a will that one hundred slaves be freed on his behalf. His son Hisham freed fifty slaves. His son Amr wanted to free the remaining fifty on his behalf, so he said: 'Until I ask the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him).' So he came to the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and said: 'O Messenger of Allah, indeed my father willed that one hundred slaves be freed on his behalf. Hisham freed fifty on his behalf, and fifty remain upon him. Should I free them on his behalf?' The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: 'If he was a Muslim, and you freed slaves on his behalf, or gave charity on his behalf, or performed Hajj on his behalf, that would reach him.' And in a narration: 'If he had affirmed Monotheism (Tawhid), and you fasted and gave charity on his behalf, that would benefit him.'
