book_title: Abridgment of the Rulings of Funerals
text: Fifth: What a person leaves behind after his death of righteous traces and ongoing charity. This is based on the saying of the Exalted: “We record what they have sent ahead and the traces they left behind,” and the saying of the Prophet ﷺ: “When a person dies, his deeds come to an end except for three things: ongoing charity, beneficial knowledge, or a righteous child who prays for him.” And from Jarir ibn ‘Abdullah رضي الله عنه who said: We were with the Messenger of Allah ﷺ at the beginning of the day when a group of people came to him—barefoot, wearing tattered striped cloaks or simple woolen garments, carrying swords, with no lower garments nor anything else. Most of them were from Mudar, rather, all of them were from Mudar. The face of the Messenger of Allah ﷺ changed— in another narration: it tightened (both expressions have the same meaning)—when he saw their state of extreme poverty. He entered his home, then came out and ordered Bilal to call the adhan. After the prayer of Dhuhr, he ascended a small pulpit and delivered a sermon. He praised Allah and glorified Him, then said: “To proceed: Allah has revealed in His Book: ‘O mankind! Fear your Lord who created you from a single soul, and created from it its spouse, and spread from the two of them many men and women. And fear Allah through whom you ask one another, and honor the ties of kinship. Indeed, Allah is ever watching over you.’ And the verse in Surah al-Hashr: ‘O you who believe! Fear Allah, and let every soul look to what it has sent forth for tomorrow. And fear Allah; indeed, Allah is fully aware of what you do. And do not be like those who forgot Allah, so He made them forget themselves. They are the defiantly disobedient. Not equal are the people of the Fire and the people of Paradise; the people of Paradise are the successful.’ Give charity before a time comes when charity will no longer be accepted from you. A man should give from his dinar, his dirham, his clothing, a measure of his wheat, a measure of his barley, a measure of his dates—even half a date. And none of you should think any form of charity insignificant.” But the people were slow to respond, and the signs of anger appeared on his face. Then a man from the Ansar came with a pouch of silver coins, and…
foot_note: 1. He specified “righteous” (child) because reward is not obtained from an unrighteous child; as for sin, the parent does not bear the sin of the child if the parent’s intention was to cultivate goodness. Mentioning the child’s supplication was for encouragement, not as a condition—because the parent receives reward from the deeds of a righteous child whether the child prays for the parent or not, like someone who plants a tree: whoever eats from its fruit grants him reward whether they pray for him or not. Likewise for the mother. This is explained in *Mubāraq al-Azhār* in the commentary on *Mashāriq al-Anwār* by Ibn al-Malik.

He said: O Messenger of Allah, this is in the path of Allah. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) took it. Then Abu Bakr stood up and gave, then Umar stood up and gave, then the Muhajirun and the Ansar stood up and gave. Then people followed in giving charities; some with a dinar, some with a dirham, some with this and some with that, until I saw two piles of food and clothes, until I saw the face of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) beaming as if it were gilded. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Whoever introduces a good practice (Sunnah Hasanah) in Islam, he will have its reward and the like of the reward of those who act upon it after him, without that decreasing anything from their rewards. And whoever introduces a bad practice (Sunnah Sayyi'ah) in Islam, upon him will be its burden and the like of the burden of those who act upon it after him, without that decreasing anything from their burdens." Then he recited this verse: {And We record what they have put forth and their footprints (traces).} He said: So he distributed it among them.' 1

Visiting Graves:
116 - Visiting graves is legislated for taking admonition from them and remembering the Hereafter, provided that one does not say at them what angers the Lord, Glory be to Him and Exalted, such as supplicating to the buried person, seeking help from him besides Allah the Exalted, or praising him excessively (*Tazkiyah*) and asserting Paradise for him, and the like. Regarding this are well-known Hadiths; there is no necessity to mention them here. Whoever wishes may refer to them in the original.

117 - Women are like men in the recommendation of visiting graves for several reasons:
First: The generality of his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): "So visit the graves," which includes women. The explanation is: When the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) forbade visiting the grave in the beginning of the matter, there is no doubt that
foot_note: 1. 1 I say: Let the noble reader reflect on the context of the Hadith and the occasion on which the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said it. It will become clear to him that using it as evidence to prove 'good innovation' (Bid'ah Hasanah) in Islam is furthest from correctness. Because there is no mention in its context of an innovation that occurred. So how can it be correct to interpret the Hadith by their saying "Whoever innovates a good innovation in Islam" as the innovators say? He (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) only said it on the occasion of the Ansari coming with his charity before others, then people followed with their charities after him. So he had the reward of his charity and the reward of their charities because he was the one who initiated ('Sanna') and started it in that gathering. Thus, the Hadith is about legislated charity and not about blameworthy innovation in a general sense. Thereby, it becomes clear to anyone with two eyes that the Hadith does not contradict his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): "Every innovation is misguidance," and that it is not permissible to specify this universal rule which he (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to teach people in their gatherings, especially in the Friday sermon.

text:
the prohibition included men and women together. When he said: "I had forbidden you from visiting graves," it was understood that he meant both genders necessarily, as he was informing them about what was in the beginning of the matter regarding the prohibition of both genders. Since the matter is so, it was necessary that the address in the second sentence of the Hadith, which is his saying: "So visit them," he intended by it both genders as well.
This is supported by the fact that the address in the rest of the actions mentioned in his narration: "And I had forbidden you from the meat of sacrificial animals beyond three days, so keep what seems good to you. And I had forbidden you from *Nabidh* (date-wine) except in a waterskin, so drink from all vessels but do not drink an intoxicant."
I say: The address in all these actions is directed to both genders definitively, just as is the case in the first address: "I had forbidden you." If it were said that the address in his saying: "So visit them" is specific to men, the order of speech would be disrupted and its elegance would be lost, a matter which is inappropriate to attribute to the one who was given comprehensive speech (*Jawami' al-Kalim*) and who is the most eloquent of those who spoke Arabic (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). The following points increase its support:
Second: Their sharing with men in the cause (*Illah*) for which visiting graves was legislated: For it softens the heart, brings tears to the eyes, and reminds of the Hereafter.
Third: That the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) granted them concession to visit graves in two Hadiths preserved for us by the Mother of the Believers Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her):
1- From Abdullah bin Abi Mulaikah: That Aisha came one day from the graveyards. I said to her: "O Mother of the Believers, where have you come from?" She said: "From the grave of Abdur-Rahman bin Abi Bakr." I said to her: "Did not the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) forbid visiting graves?" She said: "Yes, then he ordered us to visit them." And in a narration from her: "That the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) granted concession for visiting graves."
2 - From Muhammad bin Qais bin Makhramah bin Al-Muttalib that he said one day: "Shall I not tell you about myself

and my mother?" We thought he meant his mother who gave birth to him. He said: Aisha said: "Shall I not tell you about myself and the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him)?" We said: "Yes." She said: "When it was my night in which the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was with me, he turned over, placed his cloak, took off his sandals and placed them by his feet, and spread the edge of his Izar on his bed, then lay down. He stayed only until he thought I had fallen asleep, then he took his cloak slowly, put on his shoes slowly, opened the door slowly, went out, then closed it slowly. I put my shirt over my head, veiled myself, and covered myself with my Izar 1, then I set out on his track until he came to Al-Baqi'. He stood and prolonged the standing, then raised his hands three times, then turned away, so I turned away. He hastened, so I hastened. He ran (trotted), so I ran. He moved quickly, so I moved quickly. I outpaced him and entered. No sooner had I lain down than he entered. He said: 'What is the matter, O 'A'ish 2, out of breath 3 and chest heaving?' She said: I said: 'Nothing, O Messenger of Allah.' He said: 'Either you tell me or the Subtle, the Acquainted will inform me.' She said: I said: 'O Messenger of Allah, may my father and mother be sacrificed for you,' and I informed him of the news. He said: 'So you were the dark figure I saw in front of me?' I said: 'Yes.' So he nudged me in my chest a nudge 4 that hurt me, then said: 'Did you think that Allah and His Messenger would deal unjustly with you?' She said: 'Whatever people conceal, Allah knows it.' He said: 'Yes.' He said: 'Indeed Gabriel came to me when you saw. He called me but hid it from you, so I answered him and hid it from you. He was not going to enter upon you while you had laid aside your clothes. I thought you had fallen asleep, so I disliked waking you and feared you would feel lonely. He said: Indeed your Lord commands you to go to the people of Al-Baqi' and seek forgiveness for them.' She said: I said: 'How should I say to them, O Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him)?' He said: Say: "Peace be upon the people of the abodes from the believers and Muslims. May Allah have mercy on those who have gone ahead among us and those who come later. Indeed we, if Allah wills, will join you."'"

118 - However, it is not permissible for them to visit graves frequently and repeatedly, because that might lead them to violate the Sharia, such as wailing, displaying adornment (*Tabarruj*), taking graves as places for picnics, and wasting time in idle talk, as is witnessed today in some Islamic lands. This is the intended meaning - Allah willing - of the famous Hadith: "The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) cursed - and in a wording: Allah cursed - the women who frequently visit graves (*Zawwarat*)."
Al-Qurtubi said: "The curse mentioned in the Hadith is only for those who visit frequently, due to what the intensive form (*Mubalaghah*) implies. perhaps the reason is what that leads to regarding neglecting the husband's rights, *Tabarruj*, and what arises of wailing and the like. It may be said: If all of that is safe from occurring, there is no impediment to permitting them, because remembering death is needed by both men and women."
Al-Shawkani said in *Nail Al-Awtar* 4/95: "This speech is what should be relied upon in reconciling the Hadiths of the chapter which are apparently contradictory."

119 - It is permissible to visit the grave of one who died upon other than Islam for lesson/admonition only, due to the Hadith of Abu Huraira and others: The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) visited the grave of his mother, so he wept and made those around him weep. He said: "I asked my Lord for permission to seek forgiveness for her, but He did not permit me. And I asked Him for permission to visit her grave, so He permitted me. So visit the graves, for they remind of death."
The purpose of visiting graves is two things:
1- The visitor benefiting by remembering death and the dead, and that their destination is either Paradise or Hell. This is the primary purpose of the visit as indicated by the preceding Hadiths.
2- Benefiting the deceased and doing good to him by greeting him (*Salam*), supplicating, and seeking forgiveness for him. This is specific to the Muslim. Regarding this are Hadiths; I mention some of their wordings:

First: "Peace be upon you, inhabitants of a dwelling of believing people. Indeed we and you, and what you are promised tomorrow is deferred, and indeed we, if Allah wills, will join you. O Allah, forgive the people of Baqi' Al-Gharqad."
Second: "Peace be upon the people of the abodes from the believers and Muslims. May Allah have mercy on those who have gone ahead among us and those who come later. Indeed we, if Allah wills, will join you."
Third: "Peace be upon you, people of the abodes from the believers and Muslims. Indeed we, if Allah wills, will join you. You are predecessors (*Farat*) for us and we are followers for you. I ask Allah for us and for you well-being."

120 - As for reciting the Qur'an when visiting them, it has no basis in the Sunnah. Rather, the Hadiths mentioned in the previous issue imply its lack of legitimacy. For had it been legislated, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) would have done it and taught it to his companions. Especially since Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her), who is among the most beloved people to him (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), asked him what she should say if she visited the graves? So he taught her the *Salam* and supplication, and did not teach her to read Al-Fatiha or anything else from the Qur'an. If reading was legislated, he would not have concealed that from her. How so, when delaying clarification beyond the time of need is not permissible as established in the science of *Usul*? So how about concealment? Had he (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) taught them anything of that, it would have been transmitted to us. Since it has not been transmitted with an established chain, it indicates that it did not occur.
What strengthens the lack of legitimacy is his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): "Do not make your houses graveyards, for Satan flees from the house in which Surah Al-Baqarah is recited." He (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) indicated that graves are not a place for recitation according to Sharia. Therefore, he encouraged reciting the Qur'an in houses and forbade making them like graveyards where recitation is not done. As he indicated in

the other Hadith that they are not a place for prayer either, which is his saying: "Pray in your houses and do not take them as graves." Al-Bukhari titled it saying: "Chapter: The Dislike of Prayer in Graveyards," indicating by it that it implies the dislike of prayer in graveyards. Likewise, the Hadith before it implies the dislike of reciting the Qur'an in graveyards, and there is no difference. For this reason, the Madhhab of the majority of the Salaf, like Abu Hanifa, Malik, and others, was the dislike of recitation at graves. It is the saying of Imam Ahmad. Abu Dawud said in his *Masa'il* p. 158: "I heard Ahmad being asked about recitation at the grave? He said: No."

121 - It is permissible to raise hands in supplication for them, due to the Hadith of Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) who said: [Hasan] The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) went out one night, so I sent Barirah to follow him to see where he went. She said: He took the path towards Baqi' Al-Gharqad, stood at the nearest part of Al-Baqi', then raised his hands, then departed. Barirah returned to me and informed me. When I woke up in the morning, I asked him and said: "O Messenger of Allah, where did you go out tonight?" He said: "I was sent to the people of Al-Baqi' to pray for them."

122 - But he should not face the graves when supplicating for them; rather, [he should face] the Kaaba, due to his prohibition (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) of praying towards graves as will come. Supplication is the marrow of worship and its core as is known, so it has its ruling. He (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Supplication is worship," then recited: {And your Lord says, "Call upon Me; I will respond to you."}

123 - If he visits the grave of a disbeliever, he does not greet him nor supplicate for him; rather, he gives him tidings of the Fire. Such did the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) command in the Hadith of Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas who said: A Bedouin came to the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and said: "Indeed my father used to maintain ties of kinship and was... and was...

So where is he?" He said: "In the Fire." It was as if the Bedouin felt something from that, so he said: "O Messenger of Allah, then where is your father?" He said: "Wherever you pass by the grave of a disbeliever, give him tidings of the Fire." He said: So the Bedouin became Muslim later and said: "The Messenger of Allah burdened me with a weary task; I did not pass by the grave of a disbeliever except that I gave him tidings of the Fire."

124 - He should not walk between the graves of Muslims wearing his sandals, due to the Hadith of Bashir bin Al-Hanzaliyyah (Al-Khasasiyyah) mentioned previously. He said: While I was walking with the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), he came upon the graves of the Muslims... While he was walking, a glance from him fell upon a man walking among the graves wearing sandals. He said: "O owner of the *Sabtiyyah* (tanned leather shoes), throw off your *Sabtiyyah*." He looked, and when the man recognized the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), he took off his sandals and threw them.

125 - It is not legislated to place myrtle and the like of sweet-smelling plants and roses on graves, because it was not from the actions of the Salaf. Had it been good, they would have preceded us to it. Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with them both) said: "Every innovation is misguidance, even if people see it as good."

What is Prohibited at Graves.

126 - The following are prohibited at graves:
1 - Slaughtering for the sake of Allah, due to his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): "There is no *'Aqr* (slaughtering at graves) in Islam." Abdur-Razzaq bin Hammam said: They used to slaughter (*Ya'qirun*) a cow or a sheep at the grave.
2 - Raising them more than the dirt that came out of them.
3 - Coating them with plaster (*Kils*) and the like.
4 - Writing on them.

5 - Building over them.
6 - Sitting on them.
Regarding that are Hadiths:
The First: From Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) forbade plastering the grave, sitting on it, building over it, increasing upon it, or writing on it.
The Second: From Abu Sa'id - who is Al-Khudri: That the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) forbade building over the grave.
The Third: From Abu Al-Hayyaj Al-Asadi who said: Ali bin Abi Talib said to me: "Shall I not send you on what the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) sent me on? That you do not leave an image - and in a narration: a picture - in a house except that you obliterate it, nor a raised grave except that you level it."
The Fourth: From Thumamah bin Shufayy who said: We went out with Fadalah bin Ubaid to the land of the Romans, and he was the governor for Mu'awiyah over the pass (*Darb*). And in a narration: We invaded the land of the Romans, and over that army was Fadalah bin Ubaid Al-Ansari. A cousin of ours was struck (died) at Rhodes 1, so Fadalah prayed over him and stood at his grave until he buried him. When we leveled his grave over him, he said: "Flatten it over him - and in the other narration: Lighten (the mound) over him 2 - for indeed the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to command us to level the graves."
Its apparent meaning is leveling it with the ground so that it is not raised at all. This is definitively not intended, evidenced by the fact that the Sunnah is raising it about a hand-span as indicated previously. This is supported from the Hadith

itself by the saying of Fadalah "Lighten" (*Khaffifu*), meaning the dirt, so he did not order removing the dirt from it completely. This is how the scholars interpreted it. See *Al-Mirqat* 2/372.
The Fifth: From Abu Huraira that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "That one of you sits on a burning ember which burns his clothes and reaches his skin is better for him than that he sits" - and in a narration: "steps - on a grave."
The Sixth: From Uqbah bin Amir (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "That I walk on a burning ember or a sword or sew my sandal to my foot 1 is more beloved to me than that I walk on the grave of a Muslim. And I do not care whether I relieve myself in the middle of the graves or in the middle of the market."
The Seventh: From Abu Marthad Al-Ghanawi who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) say: "Do not pray towards graves and do not sit on them."

7 - Praying towards graves, due to the Hadith mentioned just now. In it is evidence for the prohibition of praying towards the grave due to the apparent prohibition, and this is the choice of Al-Nawawi. Al-Munawi said in *Fayd Al-Qadir* explaining the Hadith: "Meaning facing them due to what is in it of extreme veneration, for it is of the rank of the Deity. So he combined - meaning the Hadith in its entirety - between the prohibition of disrespect (sitting) and extreme veneration (praying towards)." Then he said in another place: "For that is disliked (*Makruh*). If a person intends seeking blessing (*Tabarruk*) in praying in that spot, he has innovated in the religion what Allah has not permitted." The intended meaning is dislike of discouragement (*Karahat Tanzih*). Al-Nawawi said: "So said our companions. If it were said it is forbidden (*Haram*) due to the apparent meaning of the Hadith, it would not be far-fetched." It is taken from the Hadith the prohibition of praying in the graveyard; it is disliked with the dislike of prohibition (*Karahat Tahrim*). It should be known that the mentioned prohibition is only if one does not intend by facing
foot_note: 1. 1 Meaning that is a difficult and severe matter if possible.

text:
the graves the veneration of them; otherwise, it is Shirk (polytheism). Sheikh Ali Al-Qari said in *Al-Mirqat* 2/372 in his explanation of this Hadith: "If this veneration was truly for the grave and its occupant, the venerator would disbelieve. So imitating it is disliked, and it should be a dislike of prohibition. In its meaning, rather more deserving than it: the placed funeral (Janazah), which is what the people of Mecca are afflicted with, where they place the funeral at the Kaaba and then face towards it."

8 - Praying at them (graves) even without facing them. Regarding this are Hadiths:
The First: From Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "The whole earth is a mosque except the graveyard and the bathroom."
The Second: From Anas: "That the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) forbade praying between graves."
The Third: From Ibn Umar from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) who said: "Make some of your prayers in your houses and do not take them as graves."
The Fourth: From Abu Huraira who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Do not make your houses graveyards. Indeed, Satan flees from the house in which Surah Al-Baqarah is recited."

9 - Building mosques over them. Regarding this are Hadiths; I mention some of them:
The First: From Aisha and Abdullah bin Abbas together, they said: When death approached the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), he began casting a sheet of his over his face. When he felt distressed by it, he uncovered his face and said while he was in that state: "The curse of Allah be upon the Jews and the Christians; they took the graves of their prophets as mosques." He was warning against what they did.

She said in a narration: "Were it not for that, his grave would have been made prominent, but he feared it would be taken as a mosque."
The Second: His saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): "O Allah, do not make my grave an idol. Allah cursed a people who took the graves of their prophets as mosques."
The Third: From Jundub who said: I heard the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) five days before he died saying: "I had brothers and friends among you, and I clear myself to Allah that I should have a specialized friend (*Khalil*) from among you, for indeed Allah the Exalted has taken me as a Khalil just as He took Ibrahim as a Khalil. If I were to take a Khalil from my Ummah, I would have taken Abu Bakr as a Khalil. Beware! Those before you used to take the graves of their prophets and righteous ones as mosques. Beware! Do not take graves as mosques; indeed I forbid you from that."
The Fourth: From Abdullah bin Masud who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) say: "Indeed, among the worst of people are those upon whom the Hour comes while they are alive, and those who take graves as mosques."
The Fifth: From Aisha who said: During the illness of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), some of his wives mentioned a church in the land of Abyssinia called Mariya. Umm Salamah and Umm Habibah had been to the land of Abyssinia, so they mentioned its beauty and its images. The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Indeed, those people, if a righteous man among them died, they built a place of worship over his grave and depicted those images in it. Those are the worst of creation in the sight of Allah on the Day of Judgment."
Taking (graves) mentioned in the preceding Hadiths includes several matters:
First: Praying towards graves facing them.
Second: Prostrating on graves.
Third: Building mosques over them.

The second meaning is apparent from "taking," and the other two, while included in it, have been specifically mentioned in the texts of some preceding Hadiths. I detailed the discussion on that and cited the sayings of scholars as evidence in our special book *Tahdhir As-Sajid min Ittikhadh Al-Qubur Masajid* (Warning the Prostrator against Taking Graves as Mosques). I mentioned the history of including the Prophetic Grave into the Noble Mosque and the contradiction to the preceding Hadiths it entails, and that prayer is not disliked in it specifically despite that. So whoever wishes for a detailed discussion on all of that, let him refer to it.

10 - Taking them as an *Eid* (festival/place of habitual return), frequented at specific times and known seasons for worship at them or otherwise, due to the Hadith of Abu Huraira (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Do not make my grave an *Eid*, and do not make your houses graveyards. And send blessings upon me wherever you are, for your blessings reach me."

11 - Traveling to them: Regarding this are Hadiths:
The First: From Abu Huraira from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) who said: "Do not saddle the mounts (travel) except - and in a narration: Travel is only undertaken - to three mosques: The Sacred Mosque, the Mosque of the Messenger (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), and Al-Aqsa Mosque."
The Second: From Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) say: "Do not saddle - and in a wording: Do not saddle the mounts except to three mosques: This mosque of mine, the Sacred Mosque, and Al-Aqsa Mosque."
The Third: From Abu Basrah Al-Ghifari that he met Abu Huraira while he was coming. He said: "Where are you coming from?" He said: "I came from At-Tur (Mount Sinai); I prayed in it." He said: "If I had caught you (before you left), you would not have gone. Indeed I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) say: 'Do not saddle the mounts except to three mosques: The Sacred Mosque, this mosque of mine, and Al-Aqsa Mosque.'"

The Fourth: From Qaza'ah who said: I wanted to go out to At-Tur, so I asked Ibn Umar. He said: "Do you not know that the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: 'Do not saddle the mounts except to three mosques: The Sacred Mosque, the Mosque of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), and Al-Aqsa Mosque.' Leave At-Tur and do not come to it."

12 - Lighting lamps at them. The evidence for that is several matters:
First: Being an introduced innovation unknown to the righteous Salaf. He (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Every innovation is misguidance, and every misguidance is in the Fire." Narrated by Al-Nasa'i and Ibn Khuzaymah in his Sahih with an authentic chain.
Second: It involves wasting wealth, which is textually forbidden as preceded in Issue 42.
Third: It involves imitation of the Magians (Majoos), the fire worshippers. Ibn Hajar the Jurist said in *Al-Zawajir* 1/134: "Our companions stated the prohibition of lamps on the grave, even if little, where neither a resident nor a visitor benefits from it. They reasoned it with extravagance, wasting wealth, and imitation of the Magians. It is not far-fetched for this to be a major sin."
I say: He did not mention, in addition to the reasoning mentioned, our first evidence, although it is a valid evidence, perhaps even the strongest evidence. Because those who light lamps on graves intend by that drawing closer to Allah the Exalted - so they claim - and do not intend illumination for a resident or visitor, evidenced by their lighting them while the sun is rising in broad daylight. So for that reason, it was a misguided innovation.

13 - Breaking their bones.

The evidence for it is his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): "Breaking the bone of the believer when dead is like breaking it when alive."
The Hadith is evidence for the prohibition of breaking the bone of the believing deceased. Therefore, it came in the books of the Hanbalis: "It is forbidden to cut any limb of the deceased, destroy his self, or burn him, even if he willed it." As in *Kashshaf Al-Qina'* 2/127. Similar is in other Madhhabs. Ibn Hajar the Jurist even asserted in *Al-Zawajir* 1/134 that it is among the major sins. He said: "Because you knew from the Hadith that it is like breaking the bone of the living."
Al-Nawawi said in *Al-Majmu'* 5/303 in summary: "It is not permissible to exhume the grave without a legal reason by agreement of the companions (of the Madhhab). It is permissible for legal reasons like what preceded in Issue 107. And in summary: It is permissible to exhume the grave if the deceased has decayed and turned to dust. Then it is permissible to bury another in it, and it is permissible to cultivate that land, build on it, and all forms of benefit and disposal in it by agreement of the companions. All this is if no trace of the deceased remains, of bone or otherwise. This varies with the variation of lands and earth, and the statement of the experts in it is relied upon."
I say: From this, you know the prohibition of what some Islamic governments commit of obliterating some Islamic graveyards and exhuming them for the sake of urban planning, without any regard for their sanctity or concern for the prohibition of treading on them, breaking their bones, and the like. Let no one imagine that the referred planning justifies such violations. Never! For it is not among the necessities; rather, it is among the luxuries for which it is not permissible to aggress against the dead. The living must organize their affairs without harming their dead. Among the wonders that draw attention is seeing these governments respecting stones

and buildings standing over some dead more than their respect for the dead themselves. For if some of these buildings like domes or churches or the like stood in the way of the claimed planning, they leave them as they are and modify the planning map for their sake to preserve them, because they consider them ancient monuments. As for the graves of the dead themselves, they do not deserve such modification in their view. Indeed, some of those governments strive - as far as we know - to make graves outside the town and prevent burial in old graves. This is another violation in my view, because it causes Muslims to miss the Sunnah of visiting graves, as it is not easy for the general public to travel long distances to be able to reach them and undertake visiting them and supplicating for them.
The motive for these violations - as I believe - is only blind imitation of materialist disbelieving Europe, which wants to eliminate every manifestation of belief in the Hereafter and everything that reminds of it. It is not observance of health rules as they claim. Had that been true, they would have hastened to combat causes whose harm no rational person doubts, such as selling alcohol and drinking it, and immorality and debauchery in their various forms and names. Their lack of concern for eliminating these apparent evils and their striving to remove everything reminding of the Hereafter and distancing it from their eyes is the greatest proof that the intent is contrary to what they claim and declare, and what their chests conceal is greater.
2 - That there is no sanctity for the bones of non-believers, due to the annexation of the bone to the believer in his saying: "Bone of the believer." It implied that the bone of the disbeliever is not so. Al-Hafiz pointed to this meaning in *Al-Fath* by his saying: "It is derived from it that the sanctity of the believer after his death remains as it was during his life." 1
From this, the answer to the question repeated on the tongues of many students in medical colleges is known, which is: Is it permissible to break bones to examine them and conduct medical investigations on them?

The Answer: That is not permissible for the bones of a believer, but it is permissible for others. This is supported by what comes in the following issue:

127 - It is permissible to exhume the graves of disbelievers because they have no sanctity, as indicated by the implication of the previous Hadith. Witness to it is the Hadith of Anas bin Malik (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) arrived and stayed in the upper part of Medina in a clan called Banu Amr bin Awf. He stayed among them for fourteen nights. Then he sent for Banu An-Najjar, and they came carrying swords. It is as if I am looking at the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) on his mount, Abu Bakr behind him, and a group of Banu An-Najjar around him, until he arrived at the courtyard of Abu Ayyub. He used to like to pray wherever prayer time caught him, and he would pray in sheep pens. He ordered the building of the mosque, so he sent for a group of Banu An-Najjar and said: "O Banu An-Najjar, name a price for this garden of yours." They said: "No, by Allah, we do not seek its price except from Allah." He said: In it were graves of polytheists, ruins, and date palms. So the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) ordered regarding the graves of polytheists, so they were exhumed; then regarding the ruins, so they were leveled; and regarding the date palms, so they were cut. They aligned the date palms in the Qiblah of the mosque and made its two jambs of stone. They began moving the rock while chanting poetry, and the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was with them saying while moving the bricks: "This load 1 is not the load of Khaibar. This is more righteous to our Lord and purer. O Allah, there is no good except the good of the Hereafter, so forgive the Ansar and the Muhajirah." And in a narration from the Hadith of Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her): "O Allah, indeed the reward is the reward of the Hereafter, so have mercy on the Ansar and the Muhajirah."

text:
Al-Hafiz (said) in *Al-Fath*: "In the Hadith is the permissibility of disposal in a graveyard owned by gift or sale, the permissibility of exhuming obliterated graves if they are not respected (sacred), the permissibility of prayer in the graveyards of polytheists after exhuming them and removing what is in them, and the permissibility of building mosques in their places."
This is the last of what Allah, Blessed and Exalted, facilitated of summarizing the rulings of funerals, asking the Master, Mighty and Majestic, to grant us a good life, to cause us to die as believers, and to join us with the righteous. And our final call is that all praise is due to Allah, Lord of the worlds.
